componenttext: No, I think if you look at the growth engines on the SQ side of the business, Steri-Safe still provides a majority of the growth on the SQ business. And in Com Sol -- Communication Solutions and Environmental Services, add some additional growth there. On the LQ side of the business, again, a majority of the growth is coming from our Sharps Management program and our Pharmaceutical Waste program. We think over time there's a lot of overlap with Pharmaceutical Waste where it lends us to get more hazardous waste out of the hospital business. But that's something that obviously we needed the infrastructure first before we can really take advantage of that opportunity across the country.

componenttext: Okay. And just my last one. You guys ruled out a broader suite of compliance solutions to the physician market. I think it was the middle of last year. Can you talk a little bit about the initial adoption of the non OSHA-focused services and maybe something about the incremental revenue opportunities you get physicians signed up for those?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, absolutely, this is Brent. One of the services we've expanded to now and kind of our suite of compliance services that we brand is overall Steri-Safe. Obviously, you're familiar with the OSHA Compliance Services. One that we've had a lot of success w
componenttext: Yes, absolutely, this is Brent. One of the services we've expanded to now and kind of our suite of compliance services that we brand is overall Steri-Safe. Obviously, you're familiar with the OSHA Compliance Services. One that we've had a lot of success with is HIPAA services, where we can help our customers better understand those regulations, set them up with the policies and procedures they need to make sure that they are appropriately living up to the guidelines. So that's just one of many other compliance services that we're offering to our customers in the SQ space.

componenttextpreview: You made an acquisition on, I guess, the hospital side, on the communications with Beryl a couple of years ago. Can you talk a little bit about how that expansion has gone over the last several years since you acquired it?
componenttext: You made an acquisition on, I guess, the hospital side, on the communications with Beryl a couple of years ago. Can you talk a little bit about how that expansion has gone over the last several years since you acquired it?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, as you know, the Beryl Health acquisition, probably over 2 years now, really got us into the -- more of the hospital or the LQ space in Communication Solutions. Prior to that, the platform that we bought was NotifyMD . It was more of an SQ p
componenttext: Yes, I think, as you know, the Beryl Health acquisition, probably over 2 years now, really got us into the -- more of the hospital or the LQ space in Communication Solutions. Prior to that, the platform that we bought was NotifyMD . It was more of an SQ play. We've seen some good growth on Beryl. It's now really combined. We don't look at it as LQ, SQ any more. We kind of look at it together. And the reason for that, Richard, is, really, some of the services like employment reminders are applicable to both the LQ and the SQ space. So again those services can be sold to doctors' offices. They're being sold to medical practices that are associated with hospitals. They could be sold to hospitals. So we kind of look of them combined now. But the Beryl acquisition was an important acquisition for us a couple of years ago and it's done well for us.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: How do you guys get paid on all this? Is it on a per call basis? Just help us out with that.
componenttext: How do you guys get paid on all this? Is it on a per call basis? Just help us out with that.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, it varies depending on the service. For instance on an after-hour answering service, a typical contract will be set up a flat monthly fee per physician per month. And for that, they get so many minutes, and if they go over that minute, there's overch
componenttext: Yes, it varies depending on the service. For instance on an after-hour answering service, a typical contract will be set up a flat monthly fee per physician per month. And for that, they get so many minutes, and if they go over that minute, there's overcharges they get for time that was over. It is included in the standard contract. For a same service, like an employment line of service, there might be a flat monthly fee again per physician per month. And we make so many outbound calls, texts or e-mails and, again, there's so much that are allotted to that monthly fee. Any overage will be charged extra at the end of the month. So it's a combination of a flat fee and a fee for volume.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: So as we think about Communication Services, I understand that it's, I guess, large quantity, and SQ or combined. But how do you go-to-market, on the hospital side, how do you sell that product? Is it just following along with the waste side of things or
componenttext: So as we think about Communication Services, I understand that it's, I guess, large quantity, and SQ or combined. But how do you go-to-market, on the hospital side, how do you sell that product? Is it just following along with the waste side of things or how do you get into the hospital to sell that product?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, good question. We use kind of a account manager specialist model. So as we talked about last quarter, all of our account managers have been trained and certified to introduce this new service to all of our hospital customers and we do that typically
componenttext: Yes, good question. We use kind of a account manager specialist model. So as we talked about last quarter, all of our account managers have been trained and certified to introduce this new service to all of our hospital customers and we do that typically to our key decision-makers during business reviews, they then pull in the specialist for Communication Solutions and then they do a joint presentation of the overall benefit for the service for the account.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Earlier, you talked about weather being $0.03 negative impact and then there was something about seasonality being $0.02 of the combination of, I guess, those 2 at $0.05. What exactly is seasonality and I guess...
componenttext: Okay. Earlier, you talked about weather being $0.03 negative impact and then there was something about seasonality being $0.02 of the combination of, I guess, those 2 at $0.05. What exactly is seasonality and I guess...

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I kind of talked about it a little bit on our earlier question, I think, it's a cost to figure out how much is seasonality, how much is weather. So we think back to the previous call and we're talking about PSC and now, our Environmental Solutions bu
componenttext: Yes, I kind of talked about it a little bit on our earlier question, I think, it's a cost to figure out how much is seasonality, how much is weather. So we think back to the previous call and we're talking about PSC and now, our Environmental Solutions business. We have discussed that the Environmental Solutions business does experience seasonality in Q1. And seasonality is a function of volume and weather. But because there was severe weather in Q1, it resulted in a larger-than-anticipated reduction in volume in Environmental Solutions. We fully anticipate that will come back. To give you a little color there, just on the Environmental Solutions side, there were some of our operating locations that we lost 1 to 2 days of business per week for 2 months straight where we're just not productive. So we had in our estimate, in our guidance, we thought to be some seasonality. The severe weather made seasonality worse. That's why we're seeing so much as weather, so much might be seasonality. We think the 2 are integrated and are connected. And that's why it's 5 -- I think to look at that is $0.05 and we think all of that's going to come back obviously, as the weather improves throughout the year.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, thank you for clarifying that. And then with respect international internal growth. Can you comment a little bit more in terms of what exactly is driving that? Is that just -- once you get these acquisitions integrated and in for a year, you're able
componenttext: Okay, thank you for clarifying that. And then with respect international internal growth. Can you comment a little bit more in terms of what exactly is driving that? Or is that more layering in, maybe the Steri-Safe and the Sharps and stuff on the international front as well?

componenttext: I think you nailed it at the last part of that question. Additional services, they really follow the same model that we do in the States where we build that customer relationship and then we introduce new services, whether that's in the SQ side, Clinical Services and continue to expand that offering with our customers. We haven't talked about it in this call but we mentioned in the past that the symmetry services have been a real hit for us in the Spain market and Portugal market, or the Bio Systems, the additional services in those regard. So what we were left to do is follow the same playbook in the U.S., which is build that customer relationship, add additional compliance services and continue to expand that relationship with our customers.

componenttext: Great question. So Q1 we had a record number of new customers and a near record number of events. The revenue, as you see, was up a little bit. componenttext: Yes, Scott. I think we've always felt very comfortable in the range to 2 to 2.5. We certainly aren't going to spend money just for the sake of spending money. We continue to be very disciplined in our other acquisitions. We have a very robust pipeline. And I wouldn't look at these from a quarter-to-quarter basis. Really, you got to look at the acquisitions that we do more on an annual basis. These things tend to come in surges. So we were good in the range there and we feel very good about both our acquisition and our capital structure.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Welcome to Stericycle's First Quarter 2015 Conference Call. I will now read the Safe Harbor statement.Statements by Stericycle in this conference call that are not strictly historical are forward-looking. Forward-looking statements involve known and unk
componenttext:
Welcome to Stericycle's First Quarter 2015 Conference Call. I will now read the Safe Harbor statement.
Statements by Stericycle in this conference call that are not strictly historical are forward-looking. Forward-looking statements involve known and unknown risks and should be viewed with caution. Factors described in the company's Form 10-K, 10-Qs as well as its other filings with the SEC could affect the company's actual results and could cause the company's actual results to differ materially from expected results. The company makes no commitment to disclose any revisions to forward-looking statements or any facts, events or circumstances after this date that may bear upon forward-looking statements.
I will now turn it over to Charlie Alutto, CEO.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: We're pleased to report our first quarter results. We feel confident about our 2015 guidance as all lines of business remain on track, despite headwinds from extreme weather in the quarter and the continued pressure from foreign exchange. Joining me on to
componenttext:
We're pleased to report our first quarter results. We feel confident about our 2015 guidance as all lines of business remain on track, despite headwinds from extreme weather in the quarter and the continued pressure from foreign exchange. Joining me on today's call to review our first quarter results will be Dan Ginnetti, CFO; and Brent Arnold, COO. 
I'll now turn it over to Dan.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Charlie. The results for the first quarter are as follows. Revenues were $663.3 million, up 16.4% from $570 million in Q1 2014. Internal growth excluding returns and recall revenues was up 6.8%. Domestic revenues were $472.2 million, of which $452
componenttext:
Thanks, Charlie. The results for the first quarter are as follows. Revenues were $663.3 million, up 16.4% from $570 million in Q1 2014. Internal growth excluding returns and recall revenues was up 6.8%. Domestic revenues were $472.2 million, of which $452.3 million was domestic-regulated waste and compliance services and $20 million was recalls and returns. Domestic internal growth, excluding recalls and returns revenues was up 6.4% consisting of SQ, up 8% and LQ, up 5%. International revenues were $191.1 million, and internal growth adjusted for unfavorable foreign exchange impact of $23.1 million was up 8%. Acquisitions contributed $86.3 million to the growth in the quarter. Gross profit was $281.3 million or 42.4% of revenues. SG&A expense including amortization was $128.3 million or 19.3% of revenues. Net interest expense was $18.6 million. Net income attributable to Stericycle was $75.5 million or $0.87 per share on an as-reported basis and $1.08 adjusted for acquisition-related expenses and other adjusted items. 
Now for the balance sheet. Our covenant debt-to-EBITDA ratio was 2.09 at the end of the quarter. The unused portion of the revolver at the end of the quarter was approximately $867 million. In the quarter, we repurchased 100,713 shares of common stock on the open market in an amount of $13.8 million. At the end of the quarter, we have authorization to purchase 4.6 million shares. Our CapEx was $21.4 million. Our DSO was 63 days. Year-to-date, as-reported cash from operations was $132.6 million. When adjusted for recall reimbursement and one timers, cash from operations was $145.3 million. 
I will now turn it over to Brent.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dan. Worldwide, we continue to use our strong free cash flow to drive our growth through acquisition. In the quarter, we closed 15 acquisitions, 4 domestic and 11 international. The international acquisitions were 3 in South Korea, 1 in Brazil, 1
componenttext:
Thanks, Dan. Worldwide, we continue to use our strong free cash flow to drive our growth through acquisition. In the quarter, we closed 15 acquisitions, 4 domestic and 11 international. The international acquisitions were 3 in South Korea, 1 in Brazil, 1 in Mexico -- I'm sorry, 3 in South Korea, 2 in Brazil, 2 in Mexico, 2 in Romania, 1 in Ireland and 1 in Spain. Revenues from the 15 acquisitions were $7.5 million in the quarter and annualized are approximately $42.5 million. Our worldwide acquisition pool remains robust with well over $100 million in annualized revenues in multiple geographies and lines of business. 
This week marks the 1-year anniversary of the PSC Environmental Services acquisition. We are very pleased to report the synergies we discussed in the areas of long-haul transportation, route density and disposal cost have been achieved. The integrated business, which will be branded as Stericycle Environmental Solutions, is positioned for future improvements, investments and growth. 
On the international front, the team continues to drive strong internal growth. We recently returned from a trip from Latin America where we reviewed our strategic growth plans, numerous continuous improvement projects, and newly acquired businesses. The international team has made significant progress in many areas and we remain excited about our growth opportunities in all geographies. 
Looking ahead, we continue to see expanding growth opportunities as Stericycle provide multiple services to help our customers improve their operations and achieve their goals. As we execute on this strategy, we can more than triple our customer revenues. 
As we celebrate Earth Day this week, we would like to thank all of our worldwide team members for their continued commitment to helping customers promote health and safeguard the environment. I'll now turn it over to Charlie.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Brent. I would now like to provide insight on our current guidance for 2015. Please keep in mind that these are forward-looking statements and our guidance does not include future acquisitions, divestitures, integration, acquisition-related and ot
componenttext:
Thanks, Brent. I would now like to provide insight on our current guidance for 2015. Please keep in mind that these are forward-looking statements and our guidance does not include future acquisitions, divestitures, integration, acquisition-related and other adjusting items.
For 2015, we believe analyst EPS estimates will be in the range of $4.64 to $4.69. We believe analyst revenue estimates for 2015 will be in the range of $2.81 billion to $2.86 billion depending on assumptions for growth and negative impact from foreign exchange rates. We anticipate 2015 internal growth rates to be: SQ, 8% to 10%; LQ, 5% to 8%; international, 6% to 9%; and recall and returns revenues between $95 million to $120 million. We believe analysts will have estimates for our 2015 free cash flow between $445 million to $456 million. 2015 CapEx is anticipated to be between $96 million to $100 million. We expect the full year as-reported tax rate to be in the range of 34.5% to 35%. 
In closing, we're very pleased with our first quarter 2015 results and remain excited about our multiple growth opportunities for 2015 and beyond. Thank you for your time today. We will now answer any questions. As a reminder, please limit yourself to one question and one follow-up question as necessary. Amy, you can now open the Q&A queue.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Nick Hiller in for Ryan Daniels. I'm just wondering if you could provide an update on Communication Services business, I guess, and a twofold question. One, how is the 2015 sales pipeline shaping up there? And two, any update on the new IT platfor
componenttext: This is Nick Hiller in for Ryan Daniels. I'm just wondering if you could provide an update on Communication Services business, I guess, and a twofold question. One, how is the 2015 sales pipeline shaping up there? And two, any update on the new IT platform as I think, that's been piloting for some time now, so just curious what benefits you're seeing and if it's ready for a broader rollout?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think on a sales pipeline, Nick, obviously, right now, comps, so we talked about before is growing at domestic averages with our new operational improvements that are ongoing and our recently trained sales force. We believe there's upside for that busin
componenttext: I think on a sales pipeline, Nick, obviously, right now, comps, so we talked about before is growing at domestic averages with our new operational improvements that are ongoing and our recently trained sales force. We believe there's upside for that business. We're really excited about the building sales pipeline we see for Communication Solutions. With respect to your question on the platform, if you remember we talked previously last year about the piloting and ongoing implementation of our infrastructure. That was going to take place at the end of 2014 and also run through 2015. I'm really excited to report that, that is on track, the team is making really good progress on the new systems and platform for the Communication Solutions business.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: And just, okay. And a related question, are the IT improvements here increasing your conviction about the ability to integrate this business more effectively, and maybe thus increasing your appetite for acquisitions in that area?
componenttext: And just, okay. And a related question, are the IT improvements here increasing your conviction about the ability to integrate this business more effectively, and maybe thus increasing your appetite for acquisitions in that area?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, great follow-on question, Nick. Absolutely, I think, it's 2 things. Obviously, the platform -- we're buying a lot of companies that are running on outdated -- antiquated and outdated systems, they lack scalability. So first benefit we get is running
componenttext: Yes, great follow-on question, Nick. Absolutely, I think, it's 2 things. Obviously, the platform -- we're buying a lot of companies that are running on outdated -- antiquated and outdated systems, they lack scalability. So first benefit we get is running on a system that runs more efficiently, is up and running and not running down, so it helps the existing business, so we feel like it's a better customer experience to our customers. But in the end, as we get all of those systems online, get all the call centers on the same system, it does make the ability to integrate much easier and hopefully reduces the time, the turnaround time to integrate the Communication Solutions acquisition, absolutely.

componenttext: This is Gunnar Hansen in for Gary Bisbee I just had a quick question I guess in -- with regards to the U.S. business, obviously, saw some deceleration there excluding returns and recall. componenttext: Yes, I think you're looking at really the revenue compared to guidance. We were about $13.8 million off of guidance. The majority of that was really due to the extreme weather impact that we had and its impact on seasonality. As well as the lower energy surcharges that we got in Q1 and that was, combined, about $11.1 million impact. We also had foreign exchange impact in the quarter that was unfavorable by about $3.5 million. The lower recall revenues were really offset by the Q1 acquisitions and improvements in the business and the net of those was up about $800,000.

componenttext: Yes, I think when you look at the growth drivers for our SQ customer base in the U.S, there are several growth drivers that drive our organic internal growth. Steri-Safe is one of them, Communication Solutions, our Hazardous Waste, our Environmental Solutions business Brent talked about, the recently completed integration of the PSC, really they all contribute. We continue to improve the Steri-Safe offering which gives us an ability to increase value for our customers and opportunity to also accelerate revenue growth and profitability.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015

componenttextpreview: Yes. The tax rate really comes from some really great execution by our tax team on the entity structure and our tax optimization strategies. And so that had great impact within the quarter that lowered it. Going forward, we don't give guidance to those on
componenttext: Yes. The tax rate really comes from some really great execution by our tax team on the entity structure and our tax optimization strategies. And so that had great impact within the quarter that lowered it. Going forward, we don't give guidance to those onetime event, the releases of statute or other entity structure. So I think for Q2, you were going to look in the range of about 35.5% to 36%. And again for the year, which will include the great work in Q1 of about 34.5% to 35%.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, thanks, Kevin. As Brent alluded to on the opening comments, we feel really good about the integration. It is complete. The areas where we said we get those integration expenses, we hit those as long-haul transportation. It's the route density, it's t
componenttext: Yes, thanks, Kevin. As Brent alluded to on the opening comments, we feel really good about the integration. It is complete. The areas where we said we get those integration expenses, we hit those as long-haul transportation. It's the route density, it's the disposal options that we have, waste disposal business. Most of our legacy volume that Stericycle had pre-PSC acquisition has been integrated. We remain really excited about future opportunity because this new infrastructure gives us a unique ability in the marketplace. And obviously, now going forward, we really want to go with the brand, which is Stericycle Environmental Solutions. We talked about in the last call, certainly, we think there's an opportunity to increase margins right now. Those margins for Com Sol are -- I'm sorry, Environmental Solutions in the mid-20s gross margins and even in the low teens, we think over a longer period of time, we can raise those to the high 20s, low 30s and the EBIT margins in Environmental Solutions in the mid- to high-teens. So certainly an opportunity there in the long run to improve the margins of that business.

componenttext: Let me take you through the Q-to-Q gross margin roll. We're very pleased with the performance in the quarter. Gross margin expanded 26 basis points Q over Q. You recall, Q4 gross margin was at 42 15. There was some unfavorability of about 45 basis points from acquisitions, weather and the weather's impact on seasonality. Those were offset by favorable impact of about 44 basis points from foreign exchange and the local revenues from our lower energy surcharges and -- or from the surcharges in project work. Our core business improved by about 27 basis points.

componenttext: No, look, let me take it a little deeper on the restructure and then I can answer your question around whether or not you'll see it in Q2, Scott. We have experience, obviously. We've experienced a large growth over several businesses the last couple of years. Following the integration of the PSC acquisition, we took the opportunity to kind of balance and optimize our structure over all of our lines of business in the U.S. We intend to reinvest those savings primarily in the area of sales and marketing across all the lines of business. And Scott, we talk about this all the time, we continually kind of reassess where we are, feed the hot hand with respect to reassessing resources and allocations. From time to time, we have things that happen in the Q. We don't expect anything sizable in the next quarter.

componenttext: First off, I guess, on this tax rate, as I'm looking at the adjusted EPS here, if the tax rate had been more of a mid-30s kind of number, you would've reported a number where that'll be less than $1, I think. And the reason that I ask, is that you say that everything is on track. But yet, next quarter, if tax rate goes back to that mid 30s range, operationally, you have to get $0.09, $0.10 better than you were this quarter. I'm just trying to square that circle in terms of -- it would seem like operationally this quarter, there were some slippage and I didn't hear what's going to change that $0.09 to $0.10 between this quarter and next quarter that's going to unwind that.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me take you through that. The Street estimates was at $1.10, we did have $0.08 of favorable result in the quarter continue with our continued tax optimization strategy. What that did is that really offset the lower recall volume, the FX headwinds
componenttext: Yes, let me take you through that. The Street estimates was at $1.10, we did have $0.08 of favorable result in the quarter continue with our continued tax optimization strategy. What that did is that really offset the lower recall volume, the FX headwinds that we experienced and majority of the impacts from the weather. But this was no doubt a very tough quarter. I'm very pleased with the team, they did a magnificent job of pulling together and executing our optimization strategy. But if you think about it a lot of the areas where we adjusted down, we fully expect that to be rebound into the next quarter and that's why what you've seen is our guidance has remained unchanged from an EPS standpoint.

componenttext: Okay, so the -- could you just run us down, just so I have this clear here. Just give us those items in EPS just so we kind of know what unwind as we go forward?

componenttext: So the weather and the seasonality, really, the extreme weather was about $0.03. The recall was about $0.04, we'd really anticipate both of those to rebound very nicely. componenttext: Sure. Al, the -- overall we don't disclose what the size per country is. We also saw the expansion of our Clinical Services business in both countries. But they're doing really nice job in particular in Argentina expanding that. So overall, I think we're excited about the different growth engines in South America but also all of our countries. They've got a lot of exciting things go on in Europe as well, with the different services their expanding there as well.

componenttext: As you know, Al, we break out Europe and other international. So Lat Am is in obviously part of that other international. It's a big part of that other international business because the other parts of that are the other Asian markets, which are much smaller.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And then my follow -- or second part question. Maybe it's a bigger picture, maybe we already appreciate it. But the weather impact, help me understand why this was so impactful here. Is this because sort of knocks the Tennessee, Kentucky down south
componenttext: Great. And then my follow -- or second part question. Maybe it's a bigger picture, maybe we already appreciate it. But the weather impact, help me understand why this was so impactful here. Is this because sort of knocks the Tennessee, Kentucky down south. And East was freezing rain and therefore trucks and routes were disrupted? Or add a little more maybe business 101 commentary on that. And then if you could tie into that, what percentage of your contracts have a feel on energy surcharges associated with them?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good. Let's start with weather first. This was probably -- I've been here a decade and this is probably the worst winter I have seen, while being at Stericycle, especially from an operational perspective. It hit us both on revenue and from a cost perspect
componenttext: Good. Let's start with weather first. This was probably -- I've been here a decade and this is probably the worst winter I have seen, while being at Stericycle, especially from an operational perspective. It hit us both on revenue and from a cost perspective. So from a revenue perspective, you mentioned that every single month, January, February and March, we had several days in each of those months where we literally could not get the trucks out in several domiciles, whether it was ice storms -- and I would tell you, the ice storms probably hurt you more than the snowstorms because as we know those Midwest states, the Tennessees, the Kentuckys in the world, the Missouris, are just not prepared to handle that kind of weather. So we really had several days we couldn't get the trucks out. And then when we did get the trucks out, only a small percentage of the trucks could actually make all the stops, which then kind of rolls over into the cost perspective. I'm now going and picking up of those stops the day after, the day after that, the next week and I'm paying overtime to get those pickups. Probably the most interesting cost that we incur this year is that I've never seen before, we literally had to shovel the roofs of several of our facilities, both plants and transfer stations in different locations. And if you've never paid for shoveling a roof, it's a very big bill. As you have to not only shovel the roof, but you then have to haul the snow away. And I got the pleasure of seeing those bills over several states and several facilities.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: And I know as you saw in California, Al, you kind of don't appreciate some of the weather out for the folks in the East Coast.
componenttext: And I know as you saw in California, Al, you kind of don't appreciate some of the weather out for the folks in the East Coast.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015

componenttext: From a fuel and energy you also asked that as well. Overall, our fuel and energy was about 5.1% for the quarter. And as you know, we don't break out kind of how many of our customers have the surcharge. But as Charlie, I think, alluded to earlier, we did face a $1.5 million headwind as our surcharges, as we address by contract, were reduced in the quarter.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Isaac Ro from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Maybe just switching gears a little bit and ask about the big picture environment for the business. I'd be curious, we've seen a couple of hospitals and labs report on overall healthcare volumes in the U.S. I'd be curious if you could maybe opine. I know
componenttext: Maybe just switching gears a little bit and ask about the big picture environment for the business. I'd be curious, we've seen a couple of hospitals and labs report on overall healthcare volumes in the U.S. I'd be curious if you could maybe opine. I know is not a direct correlation to your business. But in general what you're seeing both regards to the overall environment but also just the  [indiscernible] in which healthcare consumptions become more seasonal, if we just kind of try to normalize for the weather impact. How you think healthcare volumes looked and what your expectation is moving into the middle part of the year.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Isaac, I think that's a good question around. Is there a seasonality component now to healthcare? It's tough when you're dealing with all of the things that Brent just talked about on the weather and how much truly is a weather impact and how much is
componenttext: Yes, Isaac, I think that's a good question around. Is there a seasonality component now to healthcare? It's tough when you're dealing with all of the things that Brent just talked about on the weather and how much truly is a weather impact and how much is it that there is a feeling out there that there could be some seasonality in healthcare and a growing seasonality component to healthcare. I think it's a little too early for us to say if there is seasonality, does it impact our business. Certainly on the SQ side where we have fixed fees on some of the contracts, seasonality doesn't play into it. But when you're talking about large IDNs, large customers, you certainly -- you want to look at that. I think it's a little difficult given the quarter we just had on whether to say that it is definitely some more seasonality. I think seasonality for us, when we talk about seasonality, it impacts a little bit more on the E Sol business. We previously discussed the E Sol and experiences that we have in seasonality of Q1. It's important to understand that seasonality is a function in the on Environmental Solutions on both volume and weather. And with the severe weather we had in Q1, it resulted in a larger than anticipated reduction in volume. And to Dan's point around the bridge and what we think is going to happen in the future, we fully anticipate based on historical models that we have in that space that a majority of that will rebound in 2015 and I think you see our overall confidence in the business for the year. We feel really good about the year and that's what we want to kind of leave, that we are feeling good about the rebound in the business on both the weather and the seasonality.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's helpful color. Just 1 follow-up on M&A, you guys continue to build out the international footprint in multiple geographies. I'd be curious now that you've had a few years here to sort of get some local knowledge in some of these markets and we're s
componenttext: That's helpful color. Just 1 follow-up on M&A, you guys continue to build out the international footprint in multiple geographies. I'd be curious now that you've had a few years here to sort of get some local knowledge in some of these markets and we're seeing some follow on deals and I think you said Spain and the other parts of the EU et cetera. Can you talk a little bit about where you think it makes sense to deploy more resources versus less just given what you've learned and where we should expect you guys to be maybe more concentrated as you build scale?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think if you look at the strategy in Asia with the 3 small tuck-in acquisitions in South Korea, this also marks the 1 year anniversary of our deal in South Korea. That integration starts to take us on track. We feel really good at this point to add
componenttext: Yes, I think if you look at the strategy in Asia with the 3 small tuck-in acquisitions in South Korea, this also marks the 1 year anniversary of our deal in South Korea. That integration starts to take us on track. We feel really good at this point to add in some of those acquisitions. From an investment standpoint, it does make sense to look at the markets that we're in today because that brings on a better IRR versus the locals hurdle rate. And then overall, we continue to look at new markets. As you know, we're disciplined and opportunistic, we're looking at those and occasionally, we'll add on a new country. But really, the focus is on the countries that we're currently in. And I think, to your point, a good example of that is the 11 international acquisitions we closed in countries that were in, in the last quarter. We had a really strong acquisition quarter. We're proud of the team, the M&A team and the integration team, what they put off in Q1.

componenttext: Erin, this is Brent. Yes, good question. That acquisition, it's a small acquisition we completed in Q1 in Ireland. And where it really fits is our Expert Solutions business. So this is just a complementary compliance and auditing service that we can add to that portfolio of services to further help those customers. Again it's early on, we're still testing this space but we're excited about the opportunity.

componenttext: Yes, Erin, this is Dan. It really doesn't, there are so much overlap in our business both from a routing standpoint, the back office support we have, we share customers in both of these. It would be virtually impossible for us to be able to break that out to the level that we would be able to give you any kind of credible information to make any kind of analysis on your part.

componenttext: Okay. In your recent filing, you guys cite this business as being one of the 2 primary drivers of organic growth in the Small Quantity base. Are you willing to put some bookends around that? Is Environmental Solutions now driving half of your domestic SQ growth now? Or is it more or less than that? Is it a lot more or less than that?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, I think if you look at the growth engines on the SQ side of the business, Steri-Safe still provides a majority of the growth on the SQ business. And in Com Sol -- Communication Solutions and Environmental Services, add some additional growth there. On
componenttext: No, I think if you look at the growth engines on the SQ side of the business, Steri-Safe still provides a majority of the growth on the SQ business. And in Com Sol -- Communication Solutions and Environmental Services, add some additional growth there. On the LQ side of the business, again, a majority of the growth is coming from our Sharps Management program and our Pharmaceutical Waste program. We think over time there's a lot of overlap with Pharmaceutical Waste where it lends us to get more hazardous waste out of the hospital business. But that's something that obviously we needed the infrastructure first before we can really take advantage of that opportunity across the country.

componenttext: Okay. And just my last one. You guys ruled out a broader suite of compliance solutions to the physician market. I think it was the middle of last year. Can you talk a little bit about the initial adoption of the non OSHA-focused services and maybe something about the incremental revenue opportunities you get physicians signed up for those?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, absolutely, this is Brent. One of the services we've expanded to now and kind of our suite of compliance services that we brand is overall Steri-Safe. Obviously, you're familiar with the OSHA Compliance Services. One that we've had a lot of success w
componenttext: Yes, absolutely, this is Brent. One of the services we've expanded to now and kind of our suite of compliance services that we brand is overall Steri-Safe. Obviously, you're familiar with the OSHA Compliance Services. One that we've had a lot of success with is HIPAA services, where we can help our customers better understand those regulations, set them up with the policies and procedures they need to make sure that they are appropriately living up to the guidelines. So that's just one of many other compliance services that we're offering to our customers in the SQ space.

componenttextpreview: You made an acquisition on, I guess, the hospital side, on the communications with Beryl a couple of years ago. Can you talk a little bit about how that expansion has gone over the last several years since you acquired it?
componenttext: You made an acquisition on, I guess, the hospital side, on the communications with Beryl a couple of years ago. Can you talk a little bit about how that expansion has gone over the last several years since you acquired it?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, as you know, the Beryl Health acquisition, probably over 2 years now, really got us into the -- more of the hospital or the LQ space in Communication Solutions. Prior to that, the platform that we bought was NotifyMD . It was more of an SQ p
componenttext: Yes, I think, as you know, the Beryl Health acquisition, probably over 2 years now, really got us into the -- more of the hospital or the LQ space in Communication Solutions. Prior to that, the platform that we bought was NotifyMD . It was more of an SQ play. We've seen some good growth on Beryl. It's now really combined. We don't look at it as LQ, SQ anymore. We kind of look at it together. And the reason for that, Richard, is, really, some of the services like employment reminders are applicable to both the LQ and the SQ space. So again those services can be sold to doctors' offices. They're being sold to medical practices that are associated with hospitals. They could be sold to hospitals. So we kind of look of them combined now. But the Beryl acquisition was an important acquisition for us a couple of years ago and it's done well for us.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: How do you guys get paid on all this? Is it on a per call basis? Just help us out with that.
componenttext: How do you guys get paid on all this? Is it on a per call basis? Just help us out with that.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, it varies depending on the service. For instance on an after-hour answering service, a typical contract will be set up a flat monthly fee per physician per month. And for that, they get so many minutes, and if they go over that minute, there's overch
componenttext: Yes, it varies depending on the service. For instance on an after-hour answering service, a typical contract will be set up a flat monthly fee per physician per month. And for that, they get so many minutes, and if they go over that minute, there's overcharges they get for time that was over. It is included in the standard contract. For a same service, like an employment line of service, there might be a flat monthly fee again per physician per month. And we make so many outbound calls, texts or e-mails and, again, there's so much that are allotted to that monthly fee. Any overage will be charged extra at the end of the month. So it's a combination of a flat fee and a fee for volume.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: So as we think about Communication Services, I understand that it's, I guess, large quantity, and SQ or combined. But how do you go-to-market, on the hospital side, how do you sell that product? Is it just following along with the waste side of things or
componenttext: So as we think about Communication Services, I understand that it's, I guess, large quantity, and SQ or combined. But how do you go-to-market, on the hospital side, how do you sell that product? Is it just following along with the waste side of things or how do you get into the hospital to sell that product?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, good question. We use kind of a account manager specialist model. So as we talked about last quarter, all of our account managers have been trained and certified to introduce this new service to all of our hospital customers and we do that typically
componenttext: Yes, good question. We use kind of a account manager specialist model. So as we talked about last quarter, all of our account managers have been trained and certified to introduce this new service to all of our hospital customers and we do that typically to our key decision-makers during business reviews, they then pull in the specialist for Communication Solutions and then they do a joint presentation of the overall benefit for the service for the account.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Earlier, you talked about weather being $0.03 negative impact and then there was something about seasonality being $0.02 of the combination of, I guess, those 2 at $0.05. What exactly is seasonality and I guess...
componenttext: Okay. Earlier, you talked about weather being $0.03 negative impact and then there was something about seasonality being $0.02 of the combination of, I guess, those 2 at $0.05. What exactly is seasonality and I guess...

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I kind of talked about it a little bit on our earlier question, I think, it's a cost to figure out how much is seasonality, how much is weather. So we think back to the previous call and we're talking about PSC and now, our Environmental Solutions bu
componenttext: Yes, I kind of talked about it a little bit on our earlier question, I think, it's a cost to figure out how much is seasonality, how much is weather. So we think back to the previous call and we're talking about PSC and now, our Environmental Solutions business. We have discussed that the Environmental Solutions business does experience seasonality in Q1. And seasonality is a function of volume and weather. But because there was severe weather in Q1, it resulted in a larger-than-anticipated reduction in volume in Environmental Solutions. We fully anticipate that will come back. To give you a little color there, just on the Environmental Solutions side, there were some of our operating locations that we lost 1 to 2 days of business per week for 2 months straight where we're just not productive. So we had in our estimate, in our guidance, we thought to be some seasonality. The severe weather made seasonality worse. That's why we're seeing so much as weather, so much might be seasonality. We think the 2 are integrated and are connected. And that's why it's 5 -- I think to look at that is $0.05 and we think all of that's going to come back obviously, as the weather improves throughout the year.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, thank you for clarifying that. And then with respect international internal growth. Can you comment a little bit more in terms of what exactly is driving that? Is that just -- once you get these acquisitions integrated and in for a year, you're able
componenttext: Okay, thank you for clarifying that. And then with respect international internal growth. Can you comment a little bit more in terms of what exactly is driving that? Is that just -- once you get these acquisitions integrated and in for a year, you're able to really just ramp up and expand the current services? Or is that more layering in, maybe the Steri-Safe and the Sharps and stuff on the international front as well?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think you nailed it at the last part of that question. Additional services, they really follow the same model that we do in the States where we build that customer relationship and then we introduce new services, whether that's in the SQ side, Clinical
componenttext: I think you nailed it at the last part of that question. Additional services, they really follow the same model that we do in the States where we build that customer relationship and then we introduce new services, whether that's in the SQ side, Clinical Services and continue to expand that offering with our customers. We haven't talked about it in this call but we mentioned in the past that the symmetry services have been a real hit for us in the Spain market and Portugal market, or the Bio Systems, the additional services in those regard. So what we were left to do is follow the same playbook in the U.S., which is build that customer relationship, add additional compliance services and continue to expand that relationship with our customers.

componenttext: Just question on the RMS target, you're affirming the full year target, I believe. And you came in at $20 million here for the quarter. Just traditionally with these large projects I know are needle movers, I mean, is there something with respect to the underlying business there that gives you the conviction in that target and/or do some of the recent acquisitions you've made maybe give you the confidence coming off of what looks like a somewhat like-quarter operationally in RMS?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great question. So Q1 we had a record number of new customers and a near record number of events. The revenue, as you see, was up a little bit. It has to do with the acquisition we made and that's more call center volumes. That does come in a little over
componenttext: Great question. So Q1 we had a record number of new customers and a near record number of events. The revenue, as you see, was up a little bit. It has to do with the acquisition we made and that's more call center volumes. That does come in a little over margin. But I got to tell you, we're only 3 weeks into the second quarter. But we're doing really good. We're off to a great start there and that's why we're confident to leave that guidance at 95 to 120 so we feel really good about the start to Q2.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. Thanks -- and then maybe as a follow-up, just to leverage, you're kind of trending down towards 2x and very active in the acquisition side. Is there a level at which you feel like the business is maybe underlevered? And maybe just from some though
componenttext: Got it. Thanks -- and then maybe as a follow-up, just to leverage, you're kind of trending down towards 2x and very active in the acquisition side. Is there a level at which you feel like the business is maybe underlevered? And maybe just from some thoughts about whether you might look to get more active in deploying capital to create value if leverage blows a few times or just some thoughts around that?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Scott. I think we've always felt very comfortable in the range to 2 to 2.5. We certainly aren't going to spend money just for the sake of spending money. We continue to be very disciplined in our other acquisitions. We have a very robust pipeline. An
componenttext: Yes, Scott. I think we've always felt very comfortable in the range to 2 to 2.5. We certainly aren't going to spend money just for the sake of spending money. We continue to be very disciplined in our other acquisitions. We have a very robust pipeline. And I wouldn't look at these from a quarter-to-quarter basis. Really, you got to look at the acquisitions that we do more on an annual basis. These things tend to come in surges. So we were good in the range there and we feel very good about both our acquisition and our capital structure.

Sean McMillan, VP of Corporate Finance, you may begin your conference.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Welcome to Stericycle Second Quarter 2015 Conference Call. I will now read the safe harbor statement.This conference call may contain forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties, some of which are beyond our control. Our actual resul
componenttext:
Welcome to Stericycle Second Quarter 2015 Conference Call. I will now read the safe harbor statement.
This conference call may contain forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties, some of which are beyond our control. Our actual results could differ materially from these statements and should be viewed with caution. Factors describing the company's Forms 10-K, 10-Qs as well as its other filings with the SEC could affect the company's actual results and could cause the company's actual results to differ materially from expected results, increases in transportation and other operating costs; the level of governmental enforcement of regulations governing related waste collection and treatment; our ability to execute our acquisition strategy and to integrate acquired businesses; competition and demand for services in the regulated waste industry; political, economic and currency risks related to our foreign operations; impairments of goodwill or other in-depth intangibles; exposure to environmental liabilities; and compliance with existing and future legal and regulatory requirements; as well as other factors described in our filings with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission, including our most recently filed annual report on Form 10-K.
As a result, past financial performance should not be considered a reliable indicator of future performance, and investors should not use historical trends to anticipate future results or trends. We make no commitment to disclose any subsequent revisions to forward-looking statements.
I will now turn it over to Charlie Alutto, CEO.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sean. We are pleased to report our second quarter results. As expected, our business rebounded from the severe weather and seasonality we experienced in Q1.In addition, our recall and returns business had a very strong Q2, which included a re
componenttext:
Thank you, Sean. We are pleased to report our second quarter results. As expected, our business rebounded from the severe weather and seasonality we experienced in Q1.
In addition, our recall and returns business had a very strong Q2, which included a record number of recalls handled in the quarter. All of our lines of business continued to perform well.
Joining me on today's call to review our second quarter results will be Dan Ginnetti, CFO; and Brent Arnold, COO.
I will now turn it over to Dan.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Charlie. The results for the second quarter are as follows: Revenues was $715.7 million, up 11.7% from $640.8 million in Q2 2014. The internal growth, excluding returns and rate recall revenues was up 7.7%. Domestic revenues were $518.2 million
componenttext:
Thank you, Charlie. The results for the second quarter are as follows: Revenues was $715.7 million, up 11.7% from $640.8 million in Q2 2014. The internal growth, excluding returns and rate recall revenues was up 7.7%. Domestic revenues were $518.2 million, of which $489.9 million was domestic regulated waste and compliance services and $28.3 million was recalls and returns. Domestic internal growth, excluding recalls and returns revenues, was up 6.6% consisting of SQ up 8% and LQ up 5%.
International revenues were $197.5 million and internal growth adjusted for unfavorable foreign exchange impact of $27.3 million was up 10%. Acquisitions contributed $58.9 million to growth in the quarter. Gross profit was $305.3 million or 42.7% of revenues.
SG&A expense, including amortization, was $135.7 million or 19% of revenues. Net interest expense was $16.4 million. Net income attributable to Stericycle was $60.5 million or $0.70 per share on an as-reported basis and $1.14 adjusted for acquisition-related expenses and other adjusted items.
Now for the balance sheet. Our covenant debt-to-EBITDA ratio was 2.32x at the end of the quarter. The unused portion of the revolver at the end of the quarter was approximately $685 million. In the quarter, we repurchased 574,807 shares of common stock on the open market in an amount of $77.4 million. At the end of the quarter, we have authorization to purchase 4.1 million shares.
Our CapEx was $25.4 million. Our DSO was 66 days. Year-to-date, as-reported cash from operation was $178.7 million. When adjusted for recall reimbursement and one timers, cash from operations was $203.7 million.
I will now turn it over to Brent.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dan. Worldwide, we continued to use our strong free cash flow to drive our growth through acquisition. In the quarter, we closed 8 acquisitions, 6 domestic and 2 international. International acquisitions were in the Netherlands, which represents a
componenttext:
Thanks, Dan. Worldwide, we continued to use our strong free cash flow to drive our growth through acquisition. In the quarter, we closed 8 acquisitions, 6 domestic and 2 international. International acquisitions were in the Netherlands, which represents a new country for us and Canada. Revenues from the 8 acquisitions were $10.1 million in the quarter and annualized for approximately $48.3 million. Our worldwide acquisition pool remains robust with well over $100 million in annualized revenues in multiple geographies and lines of business.
Last year, we expanded our recall business with the acquisition of a company specializing in the automotive industry. Our combined capabilities allow us to offer our unique recall solution to the automotive sector. As a result, this contributed to a nice rebound in our recalls and returns business in the quarter.
On the international front, our success in selling multiple services resulted in strong organic growth in the quarter. We have now fully launched the service in both Brazil and Chile. Now that this solution is available in these markets, our customers can begin to enjoy the safety, compliance and sustainability benefits provided by this service offering.
Looking ahead, we continue to see expanding growth opportunities as Stericycle provide multiple services to our customers improve their operation and achieve their goals. As we execute on this strategy, we can more than triple our customer revenues.
As you all know, last week, Stericycle announced the acquisition of Shred-it International. This exciting new platform provides us an excellent opportunity to continue our organic growth, acquisition and international expansion for many years to come. We would like to thank all of the Shred-it and Stericycle team members for all of their hard work and dedication they demonstrated in making this acquisition possible.
I will now turn it over to Charlie.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Brent. I would now like to provide insight on our current guidance for 2015. Please keep in mind that these are forward-looking statements and our guidance does not include future acquisitions, divestitures, integration, acquisition related and
componenttext:
Thank you, Brent. I would now like to provide insight on our current guidance for 2015. Please keep in mind that these are forward-looking statements and our guidance does not include future acquisitions, divestitures, integration, acquisition related and other adjusting items.
For 2015, we believe analyst EPS estimates would be in the range of $4.64 to $4.69. We believe analyst revenue estimates for 2015 will be in the range of $2.84 billion to $2.88 billion depending on assumptions for growth and impact from foreign exchange rates. We anticipate 2015 internal growth rates to be SQ, 8% to 10%, LQ, 5% to 8%, international 6% to 9%, and recall and returns revenues between $100 million to $115 million. We believe analysts will have estimates for 2015 free cash flow between $445 million to $456 million.
2015 CapEx is anticipated to be between $96 million to $100 million. We expect the full year as-reported tax rate to be in the range of 34% to 34.5%.
In closing, we are very pleased with our second quarter 2015 results and remain excited about our multiple growth opportunities for 2015 and beyond. Thank you for your time today. We'll now answer any questions. As a reminder, please limit yourself to 1 question and 1 follow-up question as necessary. Blaire, you can now open the Q&A lines.

Keep in mind though as we continued to have a headwind on fuel surcharges, that does bring down the growth rates. Again, this quarter roughly about 1% in both the LQ and SQ, so it's really more a factor of the headwind associated with the fuel charges. We don't predict what fuel will turn it fourth quarter, so that's why the growth rates will remain the say for the rest of the year.

componenttext: Okay, now that's helpful color. And then Dan, a follow-up will be for you. Just talking about our gross margins, can you talk a little bit about the bridge you sometimes provide? And then any color on the absolute level, I think, might be just to touch below what we're modeling?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I'll first give you the bridge to Q-to-Q. So we're very pleased with our third straight quarter-over-quarter increase in gross margin. Our increase over Q1 was 25 basis points. So if you start with a Q1 gross margin of 42.4, the returns on the rec
componenttext: Yes. So I'll first give you the bridge to Q-to-Q. So we're very pleased with our third straight quarter-over-quarter increase in gross margin. Our increase over Q1 was 25 basis points. So if you start with a Q1 gross margin of 42.4, the returns on the recall business rebounded from the weather and seasonality, and that increased our margins by about 55 basis points. Those more than offset the unfavorable impact of about 15 basis points from acquisitions, and about 30 basis points due to our benefits related to health care claims. Our core business improved by about 60 basis points from efficiencies and slightly lower fuel expense. So our Q2 gross margin was 42.6. And I think you asked to compare that to your expectation, and I think if we looked the Street models, they were about 43.3%. And if you bridge to that acquisitions, in the quarter, we're about a 30-basis-point headwind. Customer mix, both in our recall and in our international business, unfavorably impacted us slightly by about 16 basis points. And then as I mentioned before, increases in our benefits related to health care claims were unfavorable by about 30 basis points. And then we saw some great improvements in the business of about 12 basis points over the expectations set in our prior guidance.

componenttext: Yes, I think as you said, we came across the 1-year mark on the last quarter, integration went really well. From a growth rate perspective, they're really line with overall growth rates of the business. Certainly, as additional service that adds to both LQ and SQ, so it's a contributor to both the LQ growth of that 6% to 8% -- 8% to 10% growth and the LQ, the 5% to 8% growth. So it's growing nicely. It's a lot of SQ work that we get. We do have some project work that's included in there. I think overall though, the good news there is we saw a lot of seasonality and weather impacting that business in Q1, and it came back like we thought in Q2. So they performed pretty well in the quarter.

componenttext: Yes. I think when you think about our other businesses, it gets hard to break those out because we share so many of the resources for that business. So we have operational synergies back-office synergies, that we use and that support that business a lot of shared businesses where the recall business kind of work from an operational perspective, that's operate independently out and that's why they have always kind of been reported out -- one of the reasons why some reported out separately. So right now, there is no plan to report our other segments of the business. We do get some recall outside of the U.S., but it's not material on those numbers get reported into the specific countries and our international results.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think, the revenue number actually was really good, Al. It was 28 3 for the quarter, that's the highest it's been in the previous -- for the 6 quarters. So certainly that is a good number, a nice rebound over Q1, which is a $20 million. As far as t
componenttext: Yes. I think, the revenue number actually was really good, Al. It was 28 3 for the quarter, that's the highest it's been in the previous -- for the 6 quarters. So certainly that is a good number, a nice rebound over Q1, which is a $20 million. As far as the auto sector, as Brent mentioned in his comments, we did a small acquisition in 2014. That gave us exposure to that sector, matching that -- leveraging those relationships with our call center capabilities. It, obviously, provides our customers now with a unique solution, and we believe the sector is an opportunity for both our customers and Stericycle. If you think about our capabilities, we used to serve -- we were serving the pharmaceutical industry, the medical device industry, consumer products and the food and beverage industry, we really weren't exposed to the automotive sector. Now by having that exposure to that sector, if you think about a recall event now in the U.S. really for that matter or any part of the world, we have that experience and the exposure now to all of those sector. It's really rounded out our service offerings, and the team put out a great number in Q2, at the $23.8 million level, which was a nice improvement over Q1. And like I said, the biggest number we put up in that space since beyond 2014 -- before 2014.

componenttext: This is Brian Butler in for Michael. Just wanted to ask, 1, on the working capital side, can you talk about that in the quarter? It looked like DSOs were up a little bit and working capital was fairly high. And how to think about that in the second half and where you end in the year?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So as we mentioned before, we had an incredibly strong revenue period. In fact, our growth quarter-over-quarter was up $52.3 million. And so when you look at our DSO, about 2 days of it went up, which was attributed to the growth in the quarter, that
componenttext: Yes. So as we mentioned before, we had an incredibly strong revenue period. In fact, our growth quarter-over-quarter was up $52.3 million. And so when you look at our DSO, about 2 days of it went up, which was attributed to the growth in the quarter, that really came in the latter half of the quarter and in areas that do have slightly higher DSO. We had a 1 day impact, which really a timing of adding acquisition to the balance sheet. I don't know if that coincided with the new revenue coming in. But we remain focused on this area, we really believe it will come back by the end of the year and we maintained our free cash flow guidance as a result of that. So I think what you're going to see is our working capital, that's been a strength in this company, no change to the guidance and we'll continue to put it to work with the acquisitions, share repos or maintaining our debt levels.

componenttext: Sure, Brian, this is Charlie. SQ growth as we've stated in our guidance is 8% to 10% growth. There really hasn't been a significant change to those contribution to those growth rates. Again about 40% to 50% of that organic growth is related to price and volume, and then 50% to 60% of that, so the remainder of that growth is the additional services, whether that's Steri-Safe, hazardous-waste disposal, communication solutions, they all contribute to the SQ growth.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. This was a small acquisition in 2014. They had some capabilities in items related to recalls in the auto. They did not have a call center capability. So really when you say, where are we taking it now, we're taking it more as you know, Scott, we've
componenttext: Sure. This was a small acquisition in 2014. They had some capabilities in items related to recalls in the auto. They did not have a call center capability. So really when you say, where are we taking it now, we're taking it more as you know, Scott, we've got great capabilities in our call center, not only implementation solutions, but also in our recall and returns division. So it's taking that and leveraging those relationships with over those capabilities that we have. It certainly contributed to the growth in Q2. I wouldn't say that we had other contributors as well, we had a record number of recalls for the quarter. We are building momentum in the auto sector. And we do anticipate that, that momentum will continue for the remainder of the year. Obviously, we bought up the low end of the guidance. We are still multiple blockbuster acquisitions and that's why we brought the top end down a bit. But we think the momentum, especially in the auto sector, will continue for the rest of 2015.

componenttext: Okay. And lastly, if I could sneak 1 in on tax rate. It was a little lower than we had anticipated in the quarter. The guides 34% to 34.5%, just I guess, we can back in to what second half looks right now, but just thoughts on bumpiness in tax rate?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So it's a great question there, Scott. The guided tax rate for the quarter was exact 35.5% to 36%. And while you did see an as-reported tax rate of 33.64%, this is primarily a result of the large settlement that we had discussed in an 8-K earlier all
componenttext: Yes. So it's a great question there, Scott. The guided tax rate for the quarter was exact 35.5% to 36%. And while you did see an as-reported tax rate of 33.64%, this is primarily a result of the large settlement that we had discussed in an 8-K earlier all-in the quarter. When you adjust for the settlement, the tax rate in the quarter is actually 35.5% right in line with guidance. And so as a result, we got no EPS benefit on our adjusted EPS that we reported. Going forward, in Q3, I think still the 35.5% to 36% rate is a good rate as a whole. And based on the benefit we saw in Q1, that would give you an annual tax rate of about a 34% to 34.5%.

componenttext: This is Jay for Gary. What do you guys expect to be the real driver to increase your cash EPS from 2016 and 2018? Would you include debt reduction, lock-on M&A?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm glad you brought the cash EPS and obviously, we talked about that on the PSE, I'm might add the Shred-it call that we had and the acquisition coming up. And really by eliminating the deal related amortization, we think it better represents our operati
componenttext: I'm glad you brought the cash EPS and obviously, we talked about that on the PSE, I'm might add the Shred-it call that we had and the acquisition coming up. And really by eliminating the deal related amortization, we think it better represents our operating performance. Really all that we're doing is we're taking out the amortization in that. And so the growth in our EPS really goes back to the core fundamentals of our business, continuing to be able to have strong revenue growth, saw across multiple lines of service, execute on synergies inefficiencies and that will really drive the accretion you're looking for. I want to make sure that is the question that you're asking because it's about cash EPS, some people believe our cash flow per share, and that's not the cash EPS that we're referring to. More often you're seeing cash EPS is nothing different than the adjusted EPS that we report, and then removing the deal over the rated amortization.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right, we understand that. And how do feel about synergies driving that going forward, as well?
componenttext: Right, we understand that. And how do feel about synergies driving that going forward, as well?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Jay, this is Brent. There's actually 2 categories the synergies that we're looking at. First, there's the Cintas synergy, as Shred-it acquires Cintas back in 2014. They're doing really well with regard to achieving those. Through Q1, they're 29% of the wa
componenttext: Jay, this is Brent. There's actually 2 categories the synergies that we're looking at. First, there's the Cintas synergy, as Shred-it acquires Cintas back in 2014. They're doing really well with regard to achieving those. Through Q1, they're 29% of the way home. Keep in mind, they too had 2 different operating systems and whenever you have that, it makes it hard to accomplish certain synergies until you get on the same platform. I'm happy to report that all their locations now are on SAP. So things like route density, moving customers from on-site shredding to on-site shredding to their facilities, which are under capacity which will be a nice pick up for us as we use that available capacity. All those things will contribute to growing our overall EBITDA.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015

componenttext: Okay. One more with question, how much of the revenue you lost last quarter from bad weather did you guys get back in Q2?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would say we got back everything and we talked about weather and weather-related seasonality again a new phenomena with the PSE acquisition. We feel like we've made up all the weather and the seasonality in this quarter, Jay.
componenttext: Yes, I would say we got back everything and we talked about weather and weather-related seasonality again a new phenomena with the PSE acquisition. We feel like we've made up all the weather and the seasonality in this quarter, Jay.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Sean Dodge from Jefferies.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Sean Dodge from Jefferies.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: The returns and recall business, can you give us a sense of the size of the fixed cost base there? And how quickly can you flex that up and down as you go through periods when you a few events and quarter like this where you have many?
componenttext: The returns and recall business, can you give us a sense of the size of the fixed cost base there? And how quickly can you flex that up and down as you go through periods when you a few events and quarter like this where you have many?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we talked about it before. The fixed  cost -- the team has done a really good job. The fix cost more involved in the facilities, the call center, facility that we have, also the warehouse space that we have and we take product back. When we s
componenttext: Yes, I think we talked about it before. The fixed  cost -- the team has done a really good job. The fix cost more involved in the facilities, the call center, facility that we have, also the warehouse space that we have and we take product back. When we start to get to the low-20s or high-teens, it's hard to make up that fixed costs. So you saw that was a driver of margin down in Q3, Q4, a little bit in Q1 of this year. So once we get past those low-20s, $1[ph] million that is in revenue, those fixed costs now are covenant and obviously, earnings additional margins on that. So when you talk about a lot of other costs going on there, the variable cost is more our labor. It's the retrieval labor that we have independent contractors they go out and grab the products or the nonperforming assets. It's the call center agent that we have large influx of call center work. But I would tell you that, that high when you get below the low 20s, it's tough to cover that, those fixed costs. And then the customer mix will also impact the gross margin as well.
