componenttext: Sean, this is Brent. Overall from an international margin perspective, as you know, it's greater LQ than SQ. So the good news is their LQ margins are higher in international than domestically. But overall, that provides a challenge for them. We're always working to improve that SQ-LQ mix. And one of the main ways we do that is through our Clinical Services. This quarter, we had a really good Clinical Services performance. That helps bring more margin to our business and to grow that. And we've always focused on different types of acquisitions, new services that will continue to drive our margin. Another good example of that would be our Dosimetry business that we got in, in Spain and Portugal. So again, they maybe at a lower than we'd like, but I think we're focused on raising them and a lot of that will come from SQ business.

componenttext: Yes, Adam, it's Charlie. Steri-Connect is our new operating platform for our communication solutions business, it's on track and will be completing the end of the year. We now have production clients on Steri-Connect today and we're adding new clients every week. We're also ramping up double our call, answering services clients on the new platform by the end of 2016. We said this previously, this new platform obviously, provides better quality calls and we also will come with operational efficiencies that are not available with the current legacy systems we're operating. I think, the team kudos to the team, they're doing a really good job. They're really focused on -- they were focused on the development, they're now focused on the deployment and we're really excited about that platform. And that will help us obviously, integrate faster. So once we have the platform set, we have all the customers on it. That really gives us the confidence from sales perspective, but also from an acquisition and integration standpoint as well.

componenttext: Can you comment on whether there are any operational synergies between recall and returns and PSE environmental? Or either operation still really need to be exclusive?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, actually, that's how we got into the business. We're in recalls and returns, Barbara, as you know since 2005. And we spearheaded this as that team has done an acquisition of a company called Strong Environmental, gave us additional capabilities for
componenttext: Well, actually, that's how we got into the business. We're in recalls and returns, Barbara, as you know since 2005. And we spearheaded this as that team has done an acquisition of a company called Strong Environmental, gave us additional capabilities for some hazardous-waste offerings. It also give us the capabilities on the LQ side. But they had a business called StrongPak, we had the relationships, we meaning recalls and returns had relationships with retail, and that's really the team that built that business up for us which led us to the PSE acquisition. We've done really good job on the sales and marketing side of that business. But we were lacking in the operational infrastructure. And as you know, one of the main attractions Stericycle to PSE was that operational infrastructure that they brought to us. So there were synergies there, there were opportunities to leverage relationships, and we continue to leverage those types of relationships really across all of our businesses today.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015

componenttext: Because operationally, they are separate separate. We do leverage the relationships there, but we do rund at separately. There's not a lot of operational synergy when you go and pick up our retail pharmacy, whether it be medical waste or whether it's recurring hazardous-waste or former StrongPak, which is now part of Environmental Solutions, we leverage that operational infrastructure. And then recall tends to be lumpy in an uneven business, that's one of the goods reasons why we've always got called that out from a shareholder perspective. They get clarity over that number. So but we don't share operational infrastructure to separate businesses.

componenttext: Yes, it's always a lumpy business. The team will tell you, they get frustrated because it's really hard to predict quarter-to-quarter. We do think though, we feel good about second half of the year. I think, it's more related to the auto sector where we continue to gain momentum, and that's why we feel good about the second half of the year. And really, the record number events in Q2, we've always said some of the things that we look at as signs of are we on the right track. We continue to have record number of events, some of them are small, but we know that those large blockbuster events will eventually come in. And if we continue to gain market share and get people to rather than do it themselves with the outsource at Stericycle, that we really have a good chance to build momentum in that space. So it's again, very tough to predict, but we do feel good about the second half of the year.

componenttext: Yes. Actually, the tax rate guidance is for Q3, it remains the same. The annual number is really an impact of lower tax rate that we experienced in Q1, which was the result of some consolidation of entities and some onetime tax benefits. So the tax rate as I mentioned this quarter, when you normalize it for the litigation settlement, came in exactly where we estimated to be and we think our Q3 will be about the same. And the reason also is slightly higher. It has to do with the foreign exchange impact and some of the lower revenues internationally, which is the lower tax countries. So that's why we got pushed up both in Q2 and then subsequently in Q3 and into the rest of the year, the higher end of 35.5% to 36%.

componenttext: Yes. Right now, Stericycle is not on that operating system. Too early to tell what system we ultimately go to to run the combined business. componenttext: Yes. Sure, happy to do that. Our prior guidance as you know, was $4.64 to $4.69. componenttext: Okay, great. And then, when you announced the Shred-it acquisition, you talked about $52 million of remaining synergies from the combination with primarily with the Cintas business. headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. My name is Blaire, and I'll be your conference today. At this time, I'd like to welcome everyone to Stericycle Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Sean McMillan, VP of Corporate Finance, you may begin your conf
componenttext: Good afternoon. My name is Blaire, and I'll be your conference today. At this time, I'd like to welcome everyone to Stericycle Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Sean McMillan, VP of Corporate Finance, you may begin your conference.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Welcome to Stericycle Second Quarter 2015 Conference Call. I will now read the safe harbor statement. This conference call may contain forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties, some of which are beyond our control, for example, gene
componenttext:
Welcome to Stericycle Second Quarter 2015 Conference Call. I will now read the safe harbor statement. This conference call may contain forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties, some of which are beyond our control, for example, general economic and market conditions. Our actual results could differ significantly from the results described in the forward-looking statements. Factors that could cause such differences include: Changes in governmental regulations of the collection, transportation, treatment and disposal of regulated waste; increases in transportation and other operating costs; the level of governmental enforcement of regulations governing regulated waste collection and treatment; our ability to execute our acquisition strategy and to integrate acquired businesses; competition and demand for services in the regulated waste industry; political, economic and currency risks related to our foreign operations; impairments of goodwill or other indefinite-lived intangibles; exposure to environmental liabilities; and compliance with existing and future legal and regulatory requirements as well as other factors described in our filings with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission, including our most recently filed Annual Report on Form 10-K. As a result, past financial performance should not be considered a reliable indicator of future performance, and investors should not use historical trends to anticipate future results or trends. We make no commitment to disclose any subsequent revisions to forward-looking statements.
I will now turn it over to Charlie Alutto, CEO.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sean. We are pleased to report our second quarter results. As expected, our business rebounded from the severe weather and seasonality we experienced in Q1. In addition, our recall and returns business had a very strong Q2, which included a rec
componenttext:
Thank you, Sean. We are pleased to report our second quarter results. As expected, our business rebounded from the severe weather and seasonality we experienced in Q1. In addition, our recall and returns business had a very strong Q2, which included a record number of recalls handled in the quarter. All of our lines of business continued to perform well.
Joining me on today's call to review our second quarter results will be Dan Ginnetti, CFO; and Brent Arnold, COO.
I will now turn it over to Dan.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Charlie. The results for the second quarter are as follows. Revenues was $715.7 million, up 11.7% from $640.8 million in Q2 2014. The internal growth, excluding returns and recall revenues, was up 7.7%. Domestic revenues were $518.2 million, of
componenttext:
Thank you, Charlie. The results for the second quarter are as follows. Revenues was $715.7 million, up 11.7% from $640.8 million in Q2 2014. The internal growth, excluding returns and recall revenues, was up 7.7%. Domestic revenues were $518.2 million, of which $489.9 million was domestic regulated waste and compliance services and $28.3 million was recalls and returns. Domestic internal growth, excluding recalls and returns revenues, was up 6.6% consisting of SQ up 8% and LQ up 5%. International revenues were $197.5 million, and internal growth adjusted for unfavorable foreign exchange impact of $27.3 million was up 10%. Acquisitions contributed $58.9 million to growth in the quarter. Gross profit was $305.3 million or 42.7% of revenues. SG&A expense, including amortization, was $135.7 million or 19% of revenues. Net interest expense was $16.4 million. Net income attributable to Stericycle was $60.5 million or $0.70 per share on an as-reported basis and $1.14 adjusted for acquisition-related expenses and other adjusted items.
Now for the balance sheet. Our covenant debt-to-EBITDA ratio was 2.32 at the end of the quarter. The unused portion of the revolver at the end of the quarter was approximately $685 million. In the quarter, we repurchased 574,807 shares of common stock on the open market in an amount of $77.4 million. At the end of the quarter, we have authorization to purchase 4.1 million shares. Our CapEx was $25.4 million. Our DSO was 66 days. Year-to-date, as-reported cash from operation was $178.7 million. When adjusted for recall reimbursement and onetimers, cash from operations was $203.7 million.
I will now turn it over to Brent.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dan. Worldwide, we continue to use our strong free cash flow to drive our growth through acquisitions. In the quarter, we closed 8 acquisitions, 6 domestic and 2 international. The international acquisitions were in the Netherlands, which represen
componenttext:
Thanks, Dan. Worldwide, we continue to use our strong free cash flow to drive our growth through acquisitions. In the quarter, we closed 8 acquisitions, 6 domestic and 2 international. The international acquisitions were in the Netherlands, which represents a new country for us, and Canada. Revenues from the 8 acquisitions were $10.1 million in the quarter and, annualized, are approximately $48.3 million. Our worldwide acquisition pool remains robust with well over $100 million in annualized revenues in multiple geographies and lines of business.
Last year, we expanded our recall business with the acquisition of a company specializing in the automotive industry. Our combined capabilities allow us to offer our unique recall solution to the automotive sector. As a result, this contributed to a nice rebound in our recalls and returns business in the quarter.
On the international front, our success in selling multiple services resulted in strong organic growth in the quarter. We have now fully launched the Sharps Management Service in both Brazil and Chile. Now that this solution is available in these markets, our customers can begin to enjoy the safety, compliance and sustainability benefits provided by this service offering.
Looking ahead, we continue to see expanding growth opportunities as Stericycle provides multiple services to help our customers improve their operations and achieve their goals. As we execute on this strategy, we can more than triple our customer revenues.
As you all know, last week, Stericycle announced the acquisition of Shred-it International. This exciting new platform provides us an excellent opportunity to continue our organic growth, acquisitions and international expansion for many years to come. We would like to thank all of the Shred-it and Stericycle team members for all their hard work and dedication they demonstrated in making this acquisition possible.
I will now turn it over to Charlie.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Brent. I would now like to provide insight on our current guidance for 2015. Please keep in mind that these are forward-looking statements, and our guidance does not include future acquisitions, divestitures, integration, acquisition-related an
componenttext:
Thank you, Brent. I would now like to provide insight on our current guidance for 2015. Please keep in mind that these are forward-looking statements, and our guidance does not include future acquisitions, divestitures, integration, acquisition-related and other adjusting items.
For 2015, we believe analyst EPS estimates would be in the range of $4.64 to $4.69. We believe analyst revenue estimates for 2015 will be in the range of $2.84 billion to $2.88 billion depending on assumptions for growth and impact from foreign exchange rates. We anticipate 2015 internal growth rates to be: SQ, 8% to 10%; LQ, 5% to 8%; international 6% to 9%; and recall and returns revenues between $100 million to $115 million. We believe analysts will have estimates for 2015 free cash flow between $445 million to $456 million. 2015 CapEx is anticipated to be between $96 million to $100 million. We expect the full year as-reported tax rate to be in a range of 34% to 34.5%. In closing, we're very pleased with our second quarter 2015 results and remain excited about our multiple growth opportunities for 2015 and beyond. 
Thank you for your time today. We'll now answer any questions. [Operator Instructions] Blaire, you can now open the Q&A lines.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015

componenttext: Maybe I'll start with one on the LQ growth. I know it's been 5% or the low end of guidance for a couple of quarters. And I'm curious if we should be thinking about that as kind of a more sustainable growth rate throughout the year, if there's an initiatives you have on cross-selling or any new product launches that might skew that upwards a little bit as we start looking forward.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. There's really no change to the guidance. Obviously, all, I think, the growth engines performed well, Ryan, both LQ and SQ. Keep in mind though, as we continue to have a headwind on fuel surcharges, that does bring down the growth rates, again, this q
componenttext: No. There's really no change to the guidance. Obviously, all, I think, the growth engines performed well, Ryan, both LQ and SQ. Keep in mind though, as we continue to have a headwind on fuel surcharges, that does bring down the growth rates, again, this quarter, roughly about 1% in both LQ and SQ. So it's really more a factor of the headwind associated with fuel charges. We don't predict what fuel will do for the third and fourth quarter, so that's why the growth rates will remain the same for the rest of the year.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. No, that's helpful color. And then I guess, Dan, my follow-up will be for you. Just our gross margins. Can you talk a little bit about the bridge you sometimes provide? And then any color on the absolute level? I think it might be just a touch below
componenttext: Okay. No, that's helpful color. And then I guess, Dan, my follow-up will be for you. Just our gross margins. Can you talk a little bit about the bridge you sometimes provide? And then any color on the absolute level? I think it might be just a touch below what we were modeling.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I'll first give you the bridge to Q-to-Q. So we're very pleased with our third straight quarter-over-quarter increase in gross margin. Our increase over Q1 was 25 basis points. So if you start with a Q1 gross margin of 42.4%, the returns on the re
componenttext: Yes. So I'll first give you the bridge to Q-to-Q. So we're very pleased with our third straight quarter-over-quarter increase in gross margin. Our increase over Q1 was 25 basis points. So if you start with a Q1 gross margin of 42.4%, the returns on the recall business rebounded from the weather and seasonality, and that increased our margin by about 55 basis points. Those more than offset the unfavorable impact of about 15 basis points from acquisitions and about 30 basis points due to our benefits related to health care claims. Our core business improved by about 16 basis points from efficiency and slightly lower fuel expense. So our Q2 gross margin was 42.6%. And I think you asked to compare that to your expectation. And I think if we look to The Street models, they were about 43.3%. And if you bridge to that acquisitions, in the quarter, we're about a 30 basis point headwind. Customer mix, both in our recall and our international business unfavorably impacted us slightly by about 16 basis points. And then as I mentioned before, increases in our benefits related to health care claims were unfavorable by about 30 basis points. And then we saw some great improvements in the business of about 12 basis points over the expectations set in our prior guidance.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of David Manthey from W -- Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of David Manthey from W -- Robert W. Baird.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: On the change in the revenue outlook, I assume that's pretty standard acquisitions being offset by worsening FX. Can you put any numbers around the FX piece?
componenttext: On the change in the revenue outlook, I assume that's pretty standard acquisitions being offset by worsening FX. Can you put any numbers around the FX piece?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think you're looking at the bridge to our revenue in the change in guidance there. Our previous guidance was about 2.81 to 2.86, but we had a really nice quarter. And we beat The Street estimate by about $7 million, so we raised it by about $7 mill
componenttext: Yes. I think you're looking at the bridge to our revenue in the change in guidance there. Our previous guidance was about 2.81 to 2.86, but we had a really nice quarter. And we beat The Street estimate by about $7 million, so we raised it by about $7 million there. The acquisitions that we completed in Q2 will contribute about $24 million to the year. And then we slightly narrowed the recall guidance by raising up the bottom end and then we lowered the top end each at about $5 million. So new guidance is $100 million to $115 million, and that gives you the 2.84 to 2.88 guidance.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: So there really was no impact from foreign exchange on the guidance going from this point forward, David.
componenttext: So there really was no impact from foreign exchange on the guidance going from this point forward, David.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then second, it's, I guess, a little over a year since the acquisition of PSC with synergies and accretion up to your expectations. Will you -- can you talk at all about the year-to-year growth rate that you saw in the combined PSC-StrongPak LTO
componenttext: Okay. And then second, it's, I guess, a little over a year since the acquisition of PSC with synergies and accretion up to your expectations. Will you -- can you talk at all about the year-to-year growth rate that you saw in the combined PSC-StrongPak LTO [ph] haz waste business this quarter?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think as you said, we've came across the 1 year mark on the last quarter. The integrations went really well. From a growth rate perspective, they're really line with the overall growth rates of the business, certainly as an additional service that
componenttext: Yes. I think as you said, we've came across the 1 year mark on the last quarter. The integrations went really well. From a growth rate perspective, they're really line with the overall growth rates of the business, certainly as an additional service that adds to both LQ and SQ. So it's a contributor to both the LQ growth of that 5 -- of that 6% to 8% -- 8% to 10% growth and the LQ, the 5% to 8% growth. So it's growing nicely. It's a lot of SQ work that we get. We do have some project work that's included in there. And I think overall though, the good news there is we saw a lot of seasonality and weather impacting that business in Q1, and it came back like we thought in Q2. So they performed really well in the quarter.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Al Kaschalk from Wedbush Securities.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Al Kaschalk from Wedbush Securities.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a question here, more maybe philosophical. The recalls and returns business is actually increasingly becoming a small piece. I was wondering why. Or perhaps are we going to see some additional disclosure or guidance on some of the other service lines
componenttext: Just a question here, more maybe philosophical. The recalls and returns business is actually increasingly becoming a small piece. I was wondering why. Or perhaps are we going to see some additional disclosure or guidance on some of the other service lines, particularly what we just talked about on the industrial side business?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think when you think about our other businesses, it gets hard to break those out because we share so many of the resources in that business. So we have operational synergies, back-office synergies that we use and that support that business, a lot o
componenttext: Yes. I think when you think about our other businesses, it gets hard to break those out because we share so many of the resources in that business. So we have operational synergies, back-office synergies that we use and that support that business, a lot of shared businesses where the recall business kind of, from an operational perspective, does operate independently, Al. And that's why they've always kind of been reported out, one of the reasons why that's been reported out separately. So right now, there is no plan to report out other segments of the business. We do get some recall outside of the U.S., but it's not material on those numbers get reported into the specific countries in our international results.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then my follow-up then, the automotive has actually been a good market. I noticed that the number of recalls, yes, those are record number, but the dollar level still is pretty low. So how should we be thinking about the -- your direction on thi
componenttext: Okay. And then my follow-up then, the automotive has actually been a good market. I noticed that the number of recalls, yes, those are record number, but the dollar level still is pretty low. So how should we be thinking about the -- your direction on this particular segment and then both domestically or North America? And then obviously, there's a fairly growing market opportunity in places outside of North America.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think the revenue number actually was really good, Al. It was $28.3 million for the quarter. That's the highest it's been in the previous -- for the 6 quarters. So certainly, that is a good number, a nice rebound over Q1, which is at $20 million. A
componenttext: Yes. I think the revenue number actually was really good, Al. It was $28.3 million for the quarter. That's the highest it's been in the previous -- for the 6 quarters. So certainly, that is a good number, a nice rebound over Q1, which is at $20 million. As far as the auto sector, as Brent mentioned in his comments, we did a small acquisition in 2014 that gave us exposure to that sector, matching the -- and leveraging those relationships with our call center capabilities. It obviously provides our customers now with a unique solution, and we believe the sector is an opportunity for both our customers and Stericycle. If you think about our capabilities, we used to serve -- we were serving the pharmaceutical industry, the medical device industry, consumer products and the food and beverage industry. We really weren't exposed to the automotive sector. Now by having that exposure to that sector, if you think about a recall event now in the U.S, really for that matter in any part of the world, we have that experience and the exposure now to all of those sectors. It really rounded out our service offering, and the team put out a great number in Q2 at the $23.8 million level, which was a nice improvement over Q1. And like I said, the biggest number we put up in that space since beyond 2014 -- before 2014.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Hoffman from Stifel.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Hoffman from Stifel.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Brian Butler in for Michael. Just wanted to ask. One, on the working capital side, can you talk about that in the quarter? It looked like DSOs were up a little bit, and working capital was fairly high. And how to think about that in the second hal
componenttext: This is Brian Butler in for Michael. Just wanted to ask. One, on the working capital side, can you talk about that in the quarter? It looked like DSOs were up a little bit, and working capital was fairly high. And how to think about that in the second half and where you end the year?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So as we mentioned before, we had an incredibly strong revenue period. In fact, our growth quarter-over-quarter was up $52.3 million. And so when you look at our DSO, about 2 days of it went up, which was attributed to the growth in the quarter that
componenttext: Yes. So as we mentioned before, we had an incredibly strong revenue period. In fact, our growth quarter-over-quarter was up $52.3 million. And so when you look at our DSO, about 2 days of it went up, which was attributed to the growth in the quarter that really came in the latter half of the quarter and in areas that do have slightly higher DSO. We had a 1-day impact, which really a timing of adding acquisition to the balance sheet. They don't always coincide with the new revenue coming in. But we remain focused on this area. We really believe it'll come back by the end of the year, and we've maintained our free cash flow guidance as a result of that. So I think what you're going to see is our -- the working capital that's been a strength in this company. No change to the guidance, and we'll continue to put it to work whether the acquisition, share repos or maintaining our debt levels.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then a quick follow-up on growth. Just domestically on the SQ, can you give any color on the breakdown, kind of between what is the incremental services you're selling to current customers versus kind of new customers?
componenttext: Okay. And then a quick follow-up on growth. Just domestically on the SQ, can you give any color on the breakdown, kind of between what is the incremental services you're selling to current customers versus kind of new customers?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Brian. This is Charlie. SQ growth, as we always -- as we've stated in our guidance, is 8% to 10% growth. There really hasn't been a significant change to those contribution to those growth rates. Again, about 40% to 50% of that organic growth is rel
componenttext: Sure, Brian. This is Charlie. SQ growth, as we always -- as we've stated in our guidance, is 8% to 10% growth. There really hasn't been a significant change to those contribution to those growth rates. Again, about 40% to 50% of that organic growth is related to price and volume and then 50% to 60% of that. So the remainder of that growth is in the additional services, whether that's Steri-Safe, hazardous waste disposal and Communication Solutions, they all contribute to the SQ growth.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from the line of Scott Schneeberger from Oppenheimer.
componenttext: And the next question comes from the line of Scott Schneeberger from Oppenheimer.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Going back to RMS. Could you speak a little bit more about that -- the auto acquisition? And what actually are the -- is the auto activity, recall activity you're seeing? And then is that passing through and active here at the end of the quarter and into
componenttext: Going back to RMS. Could you speak a little bit more about that -- the auto acquisition? And what actually are the -- is the auto activity, recall activity you're seeing? And then is that passing through and active here at the end of the quarter and into July? And beyond that, what else in RMS is -- is it still active? Is the trend strong into the third quarter?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. This was a small acquisition in 2014. They had some capabilities in items related to recalls in the auto. They did not have a call center capability. So really, when you say where are we taking it now, we're taking it more where, as you know, Scott,
componenttext: Sure. This was a small acquisition in 2014. They had some capabilities in items related to recalls in the auto. They did not have a call center capability. So really, when you say where are we taking it now, we're taking it more where, as you know, Scott, we've got great capabilities in call center, not only in our Communication Solutions, but also in our recall and returns division. So it's taking that and leveraging those relationships over those capabilities that we have. It certainly contributed to the growth in Q2. I wouldn't say that we had other contributors as well. We had a record number of recalls for the quarter. We are building momentum in the auto sector, and we do anticipate that, that momentum will continue for the remainder of the year. Obviously, we brought up the low end of the guidance. We're still missing some of those multiple blockbuster acquisitions, and that's why we brought the top end down a bit. But we think the momentum, especially in the auto sector, will continue for the rest of 2015.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: A couple more, still on the acquisition topic. You had 8 total: 6 U.S.; 2 international, Dutch, Canada. Could you talk about what they were LQ, SQ, other in U.S. and international, please?
componenttext: A couple more, still on the acquisition topic. You had 8 total: 6 U.S.; 2 international, Dutch, Canada. Could you talk about what they were LQ, SQ, other in U.S. and international, please?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. As you mentioned, there were 6 domestic, 2 international. They were 6 in the compliant services, 2 in console. The split of the rev SQ, LQ is about 35% SQ, 65% LQ.
componenttext: Yes. As you mentioned, there were 6 domestic, 2 international. They were 6 in the compliant services, 2 in console. The split of the rev SQ, LQ is about 35% SQ, 65% LQ.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: The comps saw both in the U.S., I assume?
componenttext: The comps saw both in the U.S., I assume?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. There was one in the U.S., one in international.
componenttext: No. There was one in the U.S., one in international.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Canada.
componenttext: Canada.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And lastly, just -- if I could sneak one in on tax rate. It was a little lower than we had anticipated in the quarter, the guide, 34% to 34.5%. Just I guess we can back in to what second half looks like now, but just thoughts on bumpiness in tax rat
componenttext: Okay. And lastly, just -- if I could sneak one in on tax rate. It was a little lower than we had anticipated in the quarter, the guide, 34% to 34.5%. Just I guess we can back in to what second half looks like now, but just thoughts on bumpiness in tax rate.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So it's a great question there, Scott. The guided tax rate for the quarter was, in fact, 35.5% to 36%. And while you did see an as-reported tax rate of 33.64%, this was primarily a result of the large settlement that we had discussed in an 8-K earlie
componenttext: Yes. So it's a great question there, Scott. The guided tax rate for the quarter was, in fact, 35.5% to 36%. And while you did see an as-reported tax rate of 33.64%, this was primarily a result of the large settlement that we had discussed in an 8-K earlier on in the quarter. When you adjust for the settlement, the tax rate in the quarter is actually 35.5%, right in line with guidance. And so as a result, we got no EPS benefit on our adjusted EPS that we reported. Going forward, in Q3, I think still the 35.5% to 36% rate is a good rate to hold. And base off the benefit we saw in Q1, that would give you an annual tax rate of about a 34% to 34.5%.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Gary Bisbee from RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Gary Bisbee from RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Jay Hanna in for Gary. What do you guys expect to be the real driver to increase your cash EPS from 2016 and 2018? Is it going to include debt reduction and lock-on M&A?
componenttext: This is Jay Hanna in for Gary. What do you guys expect to be the real driver to increase your cash EPS from 2016 and 2018? Is it going to include debt reduction and lock-on M&A?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'm glad that you brought it to cash EPS. And obviously, we talked about that on the PSC or, I might add, the Shred-it call that we had and the acquisition coming up. And really, by eliminating that deal-related amortization, we think it better repre
componenttext: Yes. I'm glad that you brought it to cash EPS. And obviously, we talked about that on the PSC or, I might add, the Shred-it call that we had and the acquisition coming up. And really, by eliminating that deal-related amortization, we think it better represents our operating performance. Really, all that we're doing is we're taking out the amortization in that. And so the growth in our EPS really goes back to the core fundamentals of our business, continuing to be able to have strong revenue growth, sell across multiple lines of service, execute on synergies and efficiencies, and that will really drive the accretion you're looking for. I want to make sure that the question that you were asking because we talked about a cash EPS, some people believe it's -- our cash flow per share, and that's not the cash EPS that we're referring to. More often, you're seeing cash EPS is nothing different than the adjusted EPS that we report and then removing the deal-related amortization.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right. No, we understand that. And how do you feel about synergies driving that going forward as well?
componenttext: Right. No, we understand that. And how do you feel about synergies driving that going forward as well?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Jay, this is Brent. There's really 2 categories of synergies that we're looking at. First, there's the Cintas synergy as Shred-it acquires Cintas back in 2014. They're doing really well with regard to achieving those. Through Q1, they're 29% of the way ho
componenttext: Jay, this is Brent. There's really 2 categories of synergies that we're looking at. First, there's the Cintas synergy as Shred-it acquires Cintas back in 2014. They're doing really well with regard to achieving those. Through Q1, they're 29% of the way home. Keep in mind, too, they had 2 different operating systems. And whenever you have that, it makes it hard to accomplish certain synergies until you get on the same platform. I'm happy to report that all of their locations now are on SAP. So things like route density, moving customers from on-site shredding to off-site shredding to their facilities, which are actually under capacity, which will be a nice pick up for us as we use that available capacity. All those things will contribute to growing our overall EBITDA.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And one more quick question. How much of the revenue you lost last quarter from bad weather? Did you guys get back in Q2?
componenttext: Okay. And one more quick question. How much of the revenue you lost last quarter from bad weather? Did you guys get back in Q2?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I would say we got back everything. And we talked about weather and weather-related seasonality, again, a new phenomena with us with the PSC acquisition. We feel like we've made up all the weather and the seasonality in this quarter, Jay.
componenttext: Yes. I would say we got back everything. And we talked about weather and weather-related seasonality, again, a new phenomena with us with the PSC acquisition. We feel like we've made up all the weather and the seasonality in this quarter, Jay.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Sean Dodge from Jefferies.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Sean Dodge from Jefferies.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: The returns and recall business, can you give us a sense of the size of the fixed cost base there? And how quickly can you flex that up and down as you go through periods where you have a few events and then quarter like this where you have many?
componenttext: The returns and recall business, can you give us a sense of the size of the fixed cost base there? And how quickly can you flex that up and down as you go through periods where you have a few events and then quarter like this where you have many?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think we talked about it before. The fixed cost -- the team has done a really good job. The fixed cost is more involved in the facilities, the call center facility that we have, also the warehouse space that we have when we take product back. When
componenttext: Yes. I think we talked about it before. The fixed cost -- the team has done a really good job. The fixed cost is more involved in the facilities, the call center facility that we have, also the warehouse space that we have when we take product back. When we start to get to the low 20s or high teens, it's hard to make up that fixed costs. So you saw that was a driver of margins down in Q3, Q4, a little bit in Q1 of this year. Then once we get past those low 20s, $1 million, that is, in revenue, those fixed costs now are coming in and, obviously, earnings additional margins on that. So when you talk about a lot of other costs to going in there, the variable cost is more of labor. It's the retrieval labor that we have, of independent contractors they go out and grab the products or the nonperforming assets, it's the call center agents that we have a large influx of call center work. But I would tell you that, that high -- when you get below the low 20s, it's tough to cover that, those fixed costs. And then the customer mix obviously would also impact the gross margin as well.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then your international segment comprised of multiple countries that are all in various stages of being built out. What's roughly the difference in margins between the most mature markets and in some of your newer ones? And any of the margins in
componenttext: Okay. And then your international segment comprised of multiple countries that are all in various stages of being built out. What's roughly the difference in margins between the most mature markets and in some of your newer ones? And any of the margins in your foreign market approaching that of United States?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, Sean, this is Brent. Overall, from an international margin perspective, as you know, it's greater LQ than SQ. So the good news is their LQ margins are higher in international than our share domestically. But overall, that provides a challenge for th
componenttext: Well, Sean, this is Brent. Overall, from an international margin perspective, as you know, it's greater LQ than SQ. So the good news is their LQ margins are higher in international than our share domestically. But overall, that provides a challenge for them. We're always working to improve that SQ-LQ mix, and one of the main ways we do that is through our Clinical Services. This quarter, we actually had a really good Clinical Services performance. That helps bring more margin to our business and helps to grow that. And we're always focused on different types of acquisitions, new services that will continue to drive our margin. Another good example of that would be our dosimetry business that we got in, in Spain and Portugal. So again, they maybe a little lower than we'd like, but I think we're focused on raising them, and a lot of that will come from SQ business.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Adam Baumgarten from Macquarie.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Adam Baumgarten from Macquarie.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Can you just give an update on the console platform and how that's going? And should we expect, as that rolls out, you guys accelerate acquisitions on that front?
componenttext: Can you just give an update on the console platform and how that's going? And should we expect, as that rolls out, you guys accelerate acquisitions on that front?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Adam, it's Charlie. The STERICONNECT is our new operating platform for our Communication Solutions business. It's on track and will be completed at the end of the year. We now have production clients on STERICONNECT today, and we're adding new client
componenttext: Yes. Adam, it's Charlie. The STERICONNECT is our new operating platform for our Communication Solutions business. It's on track and will be completed at the end of the year. We now have production clients on STERICONNECT today, and we're adding new clients every week. We're also ramping up to have all of our call answering services clients on the new platform by the end of 2016. We said this previously, this new platform obviously provides better quality calls and will also come with operational efficiencies that are not available with the current legacy systems we're operating. I think the team -- kudos to the team. They're doing a really great job. They're really focused on -- they were focused on the development, they're now focused on the deployment and we're really excited about that platform. And that will help us, obviously, integrate faster. So once we have the platform set, we have all the customers on it, that really gives us the confidence from a sales perspective, but also from a acquisition and integration standpoint as well.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Barbara Noverini from Morningstar.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Barbara Noverini from Morningstar.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Can you comment on whether there are any operational synergies between recall and returns and PSC Environmental? Specifically, I'm thinking about retail pharmacy, perhaps pharmaceutical returns. Have both entities been able to share resources or assets? O
componenttext: Can you comment on whether there are any operational synergies between recall and returns and PSC Environmental? Specifically, I'm thinking about retail pharmacy, perhaps pharmaceutical returns. Have both entities been able to share resources or assets? Or are their operations still really mutually exclusive?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, actually, that's how we got into the business. We're in recalls and returns, Barbara, as you know, since 2005. And what really spearheaded us into it is that team had done an acquisition of a company called Strong Environmental, gave us additional c
componenttext: Well, actually, that's how we got into the business. We're in recalls and returns, Barbara, as you know, since 2005. And what really spearheaded us into it is that team had done an acquisition of a company called Strong Environmental, gave us additional capabilities for some hazardous waste offerings, also give us some capabilities on the LQ side. But they had a business called StrongPak. We had the relationships -- we, meaning recalls and returns, had relationships with retail, and that's really the team that built that business up for us, which led us to the PSC acquisition. We had done a really good job on the sales and marketing side of that business, but we were lacking in the operational infrastructure. And as you know, one of the main attractions Stericycle to PSC was that operational infrastructure that they brought to us. So there are -- there were synergies there. There were opportunities to leverage relationships, and we continue to leverage those types of relationships really across all of our businesses today.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. So if that's the case, why do you still actually break out recall and returns? Why does not just assume one into the other if...
componenttext: Got it. So if that's the case, why do you still actually break out recall and returns? Why does not just assume one into the other if...

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Because operationally, they're separate. We do leverage the relationships there, but we do run that separately. There's not a lot of operational synergy when you go and pick up a retail pharmacy, for whether it be medical waste or whether it's reoccurring
componenttext: Because operationally, they're separate. We do leverage the relationships there, but we do run that separately. There's not a lot of operational synergy when you go and pick up a retail pharmacy, for whether it be medical waste or whether it's reoccurring hazardous waste or former StrongPak, which is now part of Environmental Solutions. We leverage that operational infrastructure. And then recall tends to be lumpy and uneven business. That's one of the good reasons why we've always kind of called it out from a shareholder perspective. They get clarity over that number. So -- but we don't share an operational infrastructure. They're 2 separate businesses.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Isaac Ro from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Isaac Ro from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: First, I just wanted to start off with one more on recall and returns. Just trying to figure out if there would be any sort of follow-through from the current upside this quarter that you got into 3Q and 4Q? I kind of looked at sort of the range by which
componenttext: First, I just wanted to start off with one more on recall and returns. Just trying to figure out if there would be any sort of follow-through from the current upside this quarter that you got into 3Q and 4Q? I kind of looked at sort of the range by which you raised your guidance for that business versus kind of where your numbers came out on total top line versus consensus. And it seemed like there might be a couple of million dollars of wiggle room. So I'm just trying to figure out what to assume for 3Q and if there's anything in 4Q as well.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's always a lumpy business. The team will tell you, they get frustrated because it's really hard to predict quarter-to-quarter. We do think though, we feel good about the second half of the year. I think it's more related to the auto sector, where
componenttext: Yes, it's always a lumpy business. The team will tell you, they get frustrated because it's really hard to predict quarter-to-quarter. We do think though, we feel good about the second half of the year. I think it's more related to the auto sector, where we continue to gain momentum, and that's why we feel good about the second half of the year. And really, the record number of events in Q2, we've always said some of the things that we look at as signs of are we on the right track. We continue to have record number of events. Some of them are small. But we know that the large blockbuster events will eventually come. And if we continue to gain market share and get people to -- rather than do it themselves but to outsource it to Stericycle, that we really have a good chance to build a momentum in that space. So it's, again, very tough to predict, but we do feel good about the second half of the year.

componenttext: Yes. Actually, the tax rate guidance is for the -- for Q3, it remains the same. The annual number is really an impact of the lower tax rate that we experienced in Q1, which was the result of some consolidation of entities and some onetime tax benefits. So the tax rate, as I mentioned this quarter, when you normalize it for the litigation settlement, came in exactly where we estimated it to be, and we think our Q3 will be about the same. And the reason also it is slightly higher has to do with the foreign exchange impact and some of the lower revenues internationally, which is the lower tax rate countries. And so that's why we kind of pushed up both in Q2 and then subsequently in Q3 and into the rest of the year, the higher end of 35.5% to 36%.

componenttext: Yes. Right now, no, Stericycle is not on that operating system. We'll -- too early to tell what system we ultimately go to, to run the combined business. Obviously, we have a lot on the line with the Cintas, Shred-it synergies, so we want the team to focus on that. No decisions were made on the ultimate system. We're going to learn over the next coming months more about that SAP system. As Brent kind of said in his comments, that was critical for a lot of those synergies was to get the former Cintas business on the Shred-it SAP platform.

componenttext: Yes. Sure, happy to do that. So our prior guidance, as you know, was $4.64 to $4.69. But those will be offset by some of the increases that we talked about in health care benefits. And then remember, we did lower the top end guidance on recall. So as a result, the guidance remained unchanged at $4.64 to $4.69. And just for those of you that are kind of anticipating the change to a cash EPS, the equivalent will be for $4.90 to $4.95. And I think as you're kind of building this out, ramping up from $1.18 in Q3 and then filling out your models is probably the best approach.

componenttext: Overall, our plan is to have -- by the end of this year, we hope to have 50% of the synergized -- the synergies realized of that remaining $52 million. So while the projects will wrap up in '16, the financial impact will bleed over in '17.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. My name is Blaire, and I'll be your conference today. At this time, I'd like to welcome everyone to Stericycle Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Sean McMillan, VP of Corporate Finance, you may begin your conf
componenttext: Good afternoon. My name is Blaire, and I'll be your conference today. At this time, I'd like to welcome everyone to Stericycle Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Sean McMillan, VP of Corporate Finance, you may begin your conference.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Welcome to Stericycle Second Quarter 2015 Conference Call. I will now read the safe harbor statement. This conference call may contain forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties, some of which are beyond our control, for example, gene
componenttext:
Welcome to Stericycle Second Quarter 2015 Conference Call. I will now read the safe harbor statement. This conference call may contain forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties, some of which are beyond our control, for example, general economic and market conditions. Our actual results could differ significantly from the results described in the forward-looking statements. Factors that could cause such differences include: Changes in governmental regulations of the collection, transportation, treatment and disposal of regulated waste; increases in transportation and other operating costs; the level of governmental enforcement of regulations governing regulated waste collection and treatment; our ability to execute our acquisition strategy and to integrate acquired businesses; competition and demand for services in the regulated waste industry; political, economic and currency risks related to our foreign operations; impairments of goodwill or other indefinite-lived intangibles; exposure to environmental liabilities; and compliance with existing and future legal and regulatory requirements as well as other factors described in our filings with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission, including our most recently filed Annual Report on Form 10-K. 
As a result, past financial performance should not be considered a reliable indicator of future performance, and investors should not use historical trends to anticipate future results or trends. We make no commitment to disclose any subsequent revisions to forward-looking statements.
I will now turn it over to Charlie Alutto, CEO.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sean. We are pleased to report our second quarter results. As expected, our business rebounded from the severe weather and seasonality we experienced in Q1. In addition, our recall and returns business had a very strong Q2, which included a rec
componenttext:
Thank you, Sean. We are pleased to report our second quarter results. As expected, our business rebounded from the severe weather and seasonality we experienced in Q1. In addition, our recall and returns business had a very strong Q2, which included a record number of recalls handled in the quarter. All of our lines of business continued to perform well.
Joining me on today's call to review our second quarter results will be Dan Ginnetti, CFO; and Brent Arnold, COO.
I will now turn it over to Dan.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Charlie. The results for the second quarter are as follows. Revenues was $715.7 million, up 11.7% from $640.8 million in Q2 2014. The internal growth, excluding returns and recall revenues, was up 7.7%. Domestic revenues were $518.2 million, of
componenttext:
Thank you, Charlie. The results for the second quarter are as follows. Revenues was $715.7 million, up 11.7% from $640.8 million in Q2 2014. The internal growth, excluding returns and recall revenues, was up 7.7%. Domestic revenues were $518.2 million, of which $489.9 million was domestic regulated waste and compliance services and $28.3 million was recalls and returns. Domestic internal growth, excluding recalls and returns revenues, was up 6.6% consisting of SQ up 8% and LQ up 5%. International revenues were $197.5 million, and internal growth adjusted for unfavorable foreign exchange impact of $27.3 million was up 10%. Acquisitions contributed $58.9 million to growth in the quarter. Gross profit was $305.3 million or 42.7% of revenues. SG&A expense, including amortization, was $135.7 million or 19% of revenues. Net interest expense was $16.4 million. Net income attributable to Stericycle was $60.5 million or $0.70 per share on an as-reported basis and $1.14 adjusted for acquisition-related expenses and other adjusted items.
Now for the balance sheet. Our covenant debt-to-EBITDA ratio was 2.32 at the end of the quarter. The unused portion of the revolver at the end of the quarter was approximately $685 million. In the quarter, we repurchased 574,807 shares of common stock on the open market in an amount of $77.4 million. At the end of the quarter, we have authorization to purchase 4.1 million shares. Our CapEx was $25.4 million. Our DSO was 66 days. Year-to-date, as-reported cash from operation was $178.7 million. When adjusted for recall reimbursement and onetimers, cash from operations was $203.7 million.
I will now turn it over to Brent.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dan. Worldwide, we continue to use our strong free cash flow to drive our growth through acquisitions. In the quarter, we closed 8 acquisitions, 6 domestic and 2 international. The international acquisitions were in the Netherlands, which represen
componenttext:
Thanks, Dan. Worldwide, we continue to use our strong free cash flow to drive our growth through acquisitions. In the quarter, we closed 8 acquisitions, 6 domestic and 2 international. The international acquisitions were in the Netherlands, which represents a new country for us, and Canada. Revenues from the 8 acquisitions were $10.1 million in the quarter and, annualized, are approximately $48.3 million. Our worldwide acquisition pool remains robust with well over $100 million in annualized revenues in multiple geographies and lines of business.
Last year, we expanded our recall business with the acquisition of a company specializing in the automotive industry. Our combined capabilities allow us to offer our unique recall solution to the automotive sector. As a result, this contributed to a nice rebound in our recalls and returns business in the quarter.
On the international front, our success in selling multiple services resulted in strong organic growth in the quarter. We have now fully launched the Sharps Management Service in both Brazil and Chile. Now that this solution is available in these markets, our customers can begin to enjoy the safety, compliance and sustainability benefits provided by this service offering.
Looking ahead, we continue to see expanding growth opportunities as Stericycle provides multiple services to help our customers improve their operations and achieve their goals. As we execute on this strategy, we can more than triple our customer revenues.
As you all know, last week, Stericycle announced the acquisition of Shred-it International. This exciting new platform provides us an excellent opportunity to continue our organic growth, acquisitions and international expansion for many years to come. We would like to thank all of the Shred-it and Stericycle team members for all their hard work and dedication they demonstrated in making this acquisition possible.
I will now turn it over to Charlie.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Brent. I would now like to provide insight on our current guidance for 2015. Please keep in mind that these are forward-looking statements, and our guidance does not include future acquisitions, divestitures, integration, acquisition-related an
componenttext:
Thank you, Brent. I would now like to provide insight on our current guidance for 2015. Please keep in mind that these are forward-looking statements, and our guidance does not include future acquisitions, divestitures, integration, acquisition-related and other adjusting items.
For 2015, we believe analyst EPS estimates will be in the range of $4.64 to $4.69. We believe analyst revenue estimates for 2015 will be in the range of $2.84 billion to $2.88 billion depending on assumptions for growth and impact from foreign exchange rates. We anticipate 2015 internal growth rates to be: SQ, 8% to 10%; LQ, 5% to 8%; international 6% to 9%; and recall and returns revenues between $100 million to $115 million. We believe analysts will have estimates for 2015 free cash flow between $445 million to $456 million. 2015 CapEx is anticipated to be between $96 million to $100 million. We expect the full year as-reported tax rate to be in a range of 34% to 34.5%. In closing, we're very pleased with our second quarter 2015 results and remain excited about our multiple growth opportunities for 2015 and beyond. 
Thank you for your time today. We'll now answer any questions. [Operator Instructions] Blaire, you can now open the Q&A lines.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Maybe I'll start with one on the LQ growth. I know it's been 5% or the low end of guidance for a couple of quarters. And I'm curious if we should be thinking about that as kind of a more sustainable growth rate throughout the year, if there's any initiati
componenttext: Maybe I'll start with one on the LQ growth. I know it's been 5% or the low end of guidance for a couple of quarters. And I'm curious if we should be thinking about that as kind of a more sustainable growth rate throughout the year, if there's any initiatives you have on cross-selling or any new product launches that might skew that upwards a little bit as we start looking forward.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. There's really no change to the guidance. Obviously, all, I think, the growth engines performed well, Ryan, both LQ and SQ. Keep in mind though, as we continue to have a headwind on fuel surcharges, that does bring down the growth rates, again, this q
componenttext: No. There's really no change to the guidance. Obviously, all, I think, the growth engines performed well, Ryan, both LQ and SQ. Keep in mind though, as we continue to have a headwind on fuel surcharges, that does bring down the growth rates, again, this quarter, roughly about 1% in both LQ and SQ. So it's really more a factor of the headwind associated with fuel charges. We don't predict what fuel will do for the third and fourth quarter, so that's why the growth rates will remain the same for the rest of the year.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. No, that's helpful color. And then I guess, Dan, my follow-up will be for you. Just our gross margins. Can you talk a little bit about the bridge you sometimes provide? And then any color on the absolute level? I think it might be just a touch below
componenttext: Okay. No, that's helpful color. And then I guess, Dan, my follow-up will be for you. Just our gross margins. Can you talk a little bit about the bridge you sometimes provide? And then any color on the absolute level? I think it might be just a touch below what we were modeling.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I'll first give you the bridge to Q-to-Q. So we're very pleased with our third straight quarter-over-quarter increase in gross margin. Our increase over Q1 was 25 basis points. So if you start with a Q1 gross margin of 42.4%, the returns on the re
componenttext: Yes. So I'll first give you the bridge to Q-to-Q. So we're very pleased with our third straight quarter-over-quarter increase in gross margin. Our increase over Q1 was 25 basis points. So if you start with a Q1 gross margin of 42.4%, the returns on the recall business rebounded from the weather and seasonality, and that increased our margin by about 55 basis points. Those more than offset the unfavorable impact of about 15 basis points from acquisitions and about 30 basis points due to our benefits related to health care claims. Our core business improved by about 16 basis points from efficiencies and slightly lower fuel expense. So our Q2 gross margin was 42.6%. And I think you asked to compare that to your expectation. And I think if we look to The Street models, they were about 43.3%. And if you bridge to that acquisitions in the quarter were about a 30 basis point headwind. Customer mix, both in our recall and our international business unfavorably impacted us slightly by about 16 basis points. And then as I mentioned before, increases in our benefits related to health care claims were unfavorable by about 30 basis points. And then we saw some great improvements in the business of about 12 basis points over the expectations set in our prior guidance.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think you're looking at the bridge to our revenue in the change in guidance there. Our previous guidance was about 2.81 to 2.86, but we had a really nice quarter. And we beat The Street estimate by about $7 million, so we raised it by about $7 mill
componenttext: Yes. I think you're looking at the bridge to our revenue in the change in guidance there. Our previous guidance was about 2.81 to 2.86, but we had a really nice quarter. And we beat The Street estimate by about $7 million, so we raised it by about $7 million there. The acquisitions that we completed in Q2 will contribute about $24 million to the year. And then we slightly narrowed the recall guidance by raising up the bottom end and then we lowered the top end each at about $5 million. So new guidance is $100 million to $115 million, and that gives you the 2.84 to 2.88 guidance.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015

componenttext: Okay. And then second, it's, I guess, a little over a year since the acquisition of PSC with synergies and accretion up to your expectations. Will you -- can you talk at all about the year-to-year growth rate that you saw in the combined PSC-StrongPak, LTL haz waste business this quarter?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think as you said, we've came across the 1 year mark on the last quarter. The integrations went really well. From a growth rate perspective, they're really line with the overall growth rates of the business, certainly as an additional service that
componenttext: Yes. I think as you said, we've came across the 1 year mark on the last quarter. The integrations went really well. From a growth rate perspective, they're really line with the overall growth rates of the business, certainly as an additional service that adds to both LQ and SQ. So it's a contributor to both the LQ growth of that 5 -- of that 6% to 8% -- 8% to 10% growth and the LQ, the 5% to 8% growth. So it's growing nicely. It's a lot of SQ work that we get. We do have some project work that's included in there. And I think overall though, the good news there is we saw a lot of seasonality and weather impacting that business in Q1, and it came back like we thought in Q2. So they performed really well in the quarter.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a question here, more maybe philosophical. The recalls and returns business is actually increasingly becoming a small piece. I was wondering why. Or perhaps are we going to see some additional disclosure or guidance on some of the other service lines
componenttext: Just a question here, more maybe philosophical. The recalls and returns business is actually increasingly becoming a small piece. I was wondering why. Or perhaps are we going to see some additional disclosure or guidance on some of the other service lines, particularly what we just talked about on the industrial side business?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think when you think about our other businesses, it gets hard to break those out because we share so many of the resources in that business. So we have operational synergies, back-office synergies that we use and that support that business, a lot o
componenttext: Yes. I think when you think about our other businesses, it gets hard to break those out because we share so many of the resources in that business. So we have operational synergies, back-office synergies that we use and that support that business, a lot of shared businesses where the recall business kind of, from an operational perspective, does operate independently, Al. And that's why that's always kind of been reported out, one of the reasons why that's been reported out separately. So right now, there is no plan to report out other segments of the business. We do get some recall outside of the U.S., but it's not material and those numbers get reported into the specific countries in our international results.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then my follow-up then, the automotive has actually been a good market. I noticed that the number of recalls, yes, those are record number, but the dollar level still is pretty low. So how should we be thinking about the -- your direction on thi
componenttext: Okay. And then my follow-up then, the automotive has actually been a good market. I noticed that the number of recalls, yes, those are record number, but the dollar level still is pretty low. So how should we be thinking about the -- your direction on this particular segment and then both domestically or North America? And then obviously, there's a fairly growing market opportunity in places outside of North America.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think the revenue number actually was really good, Al. It was $28.3 million for the quarter. That's the highest it's been in the previous -- for the 6 quarters. So certainly, that is a good number, a nice rebound over Q1, which is at $20 million. A
componenttext: Yes. I think the revenue number actually was really good, Al. It was $28.3 million for the quarter. That's the highest it's been in the previous -- for the 6 quarters. So certainly, that is a good number, a nice rebound over Q1, which is at $20 million. As far as the auto sector, as Brent mentioned in his comments, we did a small acquisition in 2014 that gave us exposure to that sector, matching the -- and leveraging those relationships with our call center capabilities. It obviously provides our customers now with a unique solution, and we believe the sector is an opportunity for both our customers and Stericycle. If you think about our capabilities, we used to serve -- we were serving the pharmaceutical industry, the medical device industry, consumer products and the food and beverage industry. We really weren't exposed to the automotive sector. Now by having that exposure to that sector, if you think about a recall event now in the U.S, really for that matter in any part of the world, we have that experience and the exposure now to all of those sectors. It really rounded out our service offering, and the team put out a great number in Q2 at the $28.3 million level, which was a nice improvement over Q1. And like I said, the biggest number we put up in that space since beyond 2014 -- before 2014.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
