It looks like the core business EPS growth is going to be pretty muted next year. So can you talk a little bit about that? Or maybe I'm doing some of the math wrong, but any color there?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let me help you a little bit with the math, and then I think Charlie can have a little bit of color to the future growth. When you look at the equivalent cash EPS that Charlie provided you for modeling purposes, that was the $4.69 to the $4.72. Again, thi
componenttext: Let me help you a little bit with the math, and then I think Charlie can have a little bit of color to the future growth. When you look at the equivalent cash EPS that Charlie provided you for modeling purposes, that was the $4.69 to the $4.72. Again, this year, from a tax perspective, we had 2 large legal settlements, which significantly lowered our tax rate. We also had some great entity consolidation that we did earlier in the year, which provided a much lower tax rate. So when you normalize for that tax going to the 36 because we don't expect those are going to replicate, that's about $0.12 difference. Also, the continued foreign expense or foreign exchange escalation throughout the year is about another $0.04. So when you normalize for that, you would look at about a $4.53 to a $4.56, on average, $4.55. And what that provides you is about a 16 to 17.5 probably 17 in the middle quarter over -- or year-over-year growth.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think another way to look at it, Ryan, and obviously, we're being conservative with our guidance and that's related to the strengthening of the dollar, the reduction in the industrial waste volumes and further investments in the long-term growth en
componenttext: Yes, I think another way to look at it, Ryan, and obviously, we're being conservative with our guidance and that's related to the strengthening of the dollar, the reduction in the industrial waste volumes and further investments in the long-term growth engines. This guidance will allow the Stericycle management team to focus on those areas that provide predictable revenues and outcomes. And these areas include environmental solutions, Shred-it, Communication Solutions, as well as our medical waste and compliance services. If the industrial waste volumes rebound, that will be in addition to our strong growth that we're experiencing in the overall business.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Hoffman.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Hoffman.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well I guess I'm flummoxed, which doesn't happen very often. The forecast seems about $150 million light to me on the revenues. When you think about your ending this year at about $3 billion and there's $725 million is the number that was in the presentat
componenttext: Well I guess I'm flummoxed, which doesn't happen very often. The forecast seems about $150 million light to me on the revenues. When you think about your ending this year at about $3 billion and there's $725 million is the number that was in the presentation for Shred-it, and you've got to grow the $3 billion and the $725 million has got to grow, so help me gap that difference.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think when you look at it, we think that, Michael, first of all, we think some of the industrial waste weakness that we've seen in Q3 is going to continue on and probably accelerate a little bit more in Q4, so we're being very conservative on the
componenttext: Well, I think when you look at it, we think that, Michael, first of all, we think some of the industrial waste weakness that we've seen in Q3 is going to continue on and probably accelerate a little bit more in Q4, so we're being very conservative on the industrial waste. If you think about our industrial waste part of the business, we've got about $125 million to $200 million of our regulated waste services that we feel is directly related to project or industrial waste business. So we think that slowdown, which we saw accelerate in Q3, is going to actually get worse in Q4 and then level off in 2016. Then we add the additional effect of the foreign exchange. Dan can walk you through some of those bridges, but we certainly have the additional foreign exchange headwind. It not only affected us this quarter, but if we'll use this rate going forward, which we do, it has an impact going into 2016 as well.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So just to be clear, you're roughly at $520 million of hazardous waste, $125 million to $200 million that's project-based. And you see that number becoming what?
componenttext: So just to be clear, you're roughly at $520 million of hazardous waste, $125 million to $200 million that's project-based. And you see that number becoming what?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we think that number for next year will be -- well, for next quarter, it could be down anywhere between $14 million -- $18 million to $20 million. And we were impacted roughly by about $8 million to $10 million in this quarter. So if you take that w
componenttext: Well, we think that number for next year will be -- well, for next quarter, it could be down anywhere between $14 million -- $18 million to $20 million. And we were impacted roughly by about $8 million to $10 million in this quarter. So if you take that weakness that we're showing in Q4 and you take that out into 2016, that right there is anywhere between $60 million to $70 million.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of David Manthey.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of David Manthey.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess, Q2, I'm wondering on the gross margin. Maybe you can get -- break that part a little bit. Some of the items that you mentioned here in terms of SG&A investments and professional fees, clearly, those are more SG&A related. And on the GP, we've nev
componenttext: I guess, Q2, I'm wondering on the gross margin. Maybe you can get -- break that part a little bit. Some of the items that you mentioned here in terms of SG&A investments and professional fees, clearly, those are more SG&A related. And on the GP, we've never really seen a drop like this. Is it that the profitability of this industrial waste is much higher than average or just a lack of absorption? What's the underlying cause of that, the gross margin weakness?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, David, I'll tell you. Why don't I start with the bridge and I'll add a little bit of color to that? So Q2 gross margins were $42.66 million. We did some acquisitions, but the impact that was offset directly with foreign exchange. We did have 40 basi
componenttext: Sure, David, I'll tell you. Why don't I start with the bridge and I'll add a little bit of color to that? So Q2 gross margins were $42.66 million. We did some acquisitions, but the impact that was offset directly with foreign exchange. We did have 40 basis points of unfavorable impact that came from the lower-than-expected project work. And we had some higher-than-anticipated cost of revenues, about 51 basis points of unfavorability. What those [indiscernible] that you asked about, those were redirection of waste flows required from 2 facility fires, payroll adjustment required by unions due to 2 -- due to inflation in 2 Latin American countries. We've experienced some higher operational costs from running our newly compliant Title V incinerators. Regarding the project work, yes, that does come out as higher. We have a certain amount of -- a significant amount of fixed cost that are tied to the industry. And when that revenue comes in, we're able to leverage those resources and go at them. We do have a plan going forward that Charlie had talked about on how to maybe flex that a little bit. But when that revenue comes off, we have to maintain the integrity of our fixed costs in our fleet to be able to continue to service that recurring business.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think as Dan said, Dave, the current fixed cost structure in environmental solutions, coupled with that unexpected lower revenues, unfavorably impacted revenues. I think the bigger question is what are we going to do to mitigate that in the future?
componenttext: Yes, I think as Dan said, Dave, the current fixed cost structure in environmental solutions, coupled with that unexpected lower revenues, unfavorably impacted revenues. I think the bigger question is what are we going to do to mitigate that in the future? Well, we're certainly going to implement plans to reduce those fixed cost within the business. If you think back, this is very similar to our approach and success we had in our recall business, where they solely have a business-based on project work. So we do need to mitigate that in the future by lowering those fixed costs on our environmental solutions out of the business.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on the SQ, LQ and international, unless I missed something, it seems like you adjusted those ranges. Is that correct? Or did I miss something here?
componenttext: Okay. And then on the SQ, LQ and international, unless I missed something, it seems like you adjusted those ranges. Is that correct? Or did I miss something here?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, you're correct on that. The growth engines performed well when we look at it from an additional services perspective, but certainly, we had headwinds related to fuel surcharges and those hazardous waste volumes. So we have adjusted the domestic LQ and
componenttext: No, you're correct on that. The growth engines performed well when we look at it from an additional services perspective, but certainly, we had headwinds related to fuel surcharges and those hazardous waste volumes. So we have adjusted the domestic LQ and SQ growth rates for 2015 and 2016, based on our assumptions that the headwinds, which we've outlined will remain -- will be in effect for 2015 and remain for 2016 as well.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Gary Bisbee.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Gary Bisbee.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Let me add to that. I mean, the industrial waste and project work, can you give us a little more color exactly what that is? I assume that came through PSC and was not something you built organically. But it begs the question, is that really somethin
componenttext: Yes. Let me add to that. I mean, the industrial waste and project work, can you give us a little more color exactly what that is? I assume that came through PSC and was not something you built organically. But it begs the question, is that really something we should be in, given it seems like pretty potentially volatile, and in 2 out of 3 quarters, this was a factor that led to a miss?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's a good question, so let's look at it. So our Q3 industrial wastes volumes worldwide were less than we anticipated. And Gary, that includes project work and lower volumes from the industrial waste customers. Obviously, we feel the shortfall in the p
componenttext: That's a good question, so let's look at it. So our Q3 industrial wastes volumes worldwide were less than we anticipated. And Gary, that includes project work and lower volumes from the industrial waste customers. Obviously, we feel the shortfall in the projects and these volumes are directly related to the drop in energy and commodity prices. And I think you kind of said it. We acquired assets over the last several years that included industrial waste customers, and these customers' volumes obviously are now included in our base business. So certainly, from a guidance perspective, since we thought that this pressure will not only continue to get slightly worse for the remainder of 2015, level out in 2016, that's why we took it out of our guidance in 2015 and for 2016. But it's certainly the acquisitions we've made were a portion of the businesses. I think you're absolutely right about that shouldn't be our focus. All along, we've talked about building an SQ recurring revenue model. We are certainly going to do that. We'll look at that with a little more gusto now that we've seen that project work, fluctuate more than we like. We saw it fluctuate in Q1. It came back in Q2. We thought we were going to be right there in Q3 and Q4, so this cost [ph] is obviously built during the quarter, but the focus will be over time is to transition this project in industrial waste work, which is not our core focus, to a more SQ recurring revenue model. For instance, like Steri-Safe for customers.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then a follow-up question, just on Shred-it. Can you -- within that guidance, I realized you may not break it down in a detailed fashion going forward, but can you give us a sense what is implied for Shred-it? Whether that's on the revenu
componenttext: Okay, great. And then a follow-up question, just on Shred-it. Can you -- within that guidance, I realized you may not break it down in a detailed fashion going forward, but can you give us a sense what is implied for Shred-it? Whether that's on the revenue line or the EBITDA line? Or just give us -- help us get to this new guidance frame what's in there for Shred-it?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Gary. I think when you're modeling for 2016, about $716 million is an appropriate range. Looking after EBIT, and I would urge you to look at us from an EBIT perspective as well, as we transition Shred-it which is a Canadian-owned company over to U.S
componenttext: Sure, Gary. I think when you're modeling for 2016, about $716 million is an appropriate range. Looking after EBIT, and I would urge you to look at us from an EBIT perspective as well, as we transition Shred-it which is a Canadian-owned company over to U.S. GAAP, IFRS to GAAP requires some changes. And so we'll see potentially some movements within gross margin and SG&A, but EBIT should be consistent. So I would model at about 16.7% for their EBIT. The depreciation in their model and amortization is about $56 million depreciation and $30 million amortization. And then figure about $35 million to $40 million in interest.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Scott Schneeberger.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Scott Schneeberger.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: You just mentioned on the last question that the hidden industrial waste came on quickly. It got you a little offguard. Could take us a little bit more in depth into what exactly happened, what exactly is it? And you're speaking to stabilization in 2016.
componenttext: You just mentioned on the last question that the hidden industrial waste came on quickly. It got you a little offguard. Could take us a little bit more in depth into what exactly happened, what exactly is it? And you're speaking to stabilization in 2016. Could you elaborate a little bit on, it's going to get worse in fourth quarter from third, stable in fourth quarter? Please kind of speak to what happened and what gives you the outlook of stabilization next year.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I think just to paint the picture clearer, so we had obviously an impact in Q3. We think that impact will get slightly worse in Q4 and then it will stay at that level into 2016. So it will stay at that level, at least from a guidance perspective.
componenttext: Yes. So I think just to paint the picture clearer, so we had obviously an impact in Q3. We think that impact will get slightly worse in Q4 and then it will stay at that level into 2016. So it will stay at that level, at least from a guidance perspective. And we might prove out to be too conservative on that, but we think it's prudent to have that view of the business at this point. To give you an example, Scott, on what do we mean by that type of work, I'll give you kind of 2 examples. And I think if you think through, as I said before, although we don't directly work with energy or mining companies, many of our customers do work for these industries. So the rate of decline, when we look at these customers, was much faster than we anticipated, and it declined rapidly in the quarter. So 2 examples I think we look at, we've had that's servicing and customer for several years that provides generators to the oil and gas industry. This customer provided very steady volumes over the last several years. Their business was down by over 70%, when we look at that specific example, Q3 year-over-year. Another example, we had a contract with a customer that provides equipment cleaning services for the energy and the mining industry. In Q3, we experienced an 80% decline, again, related to the energy and commodity prices. So they're just 2 examples. Obviously, we've been negatively impacted from this. And I think as we stated, we just really want to be very conservative on the guidance, that's why we're taking guidance down for the rest of the year and having that continued to the business in 2016. If it comes back, it will just be additive to our growing core business.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Charlie, you mentioned -- worldwide, could you give us a little bit of help on what's domestic and what's outside the U.S? And in the U.S., geographically, are we in the oil patches where is this mostly occurring, and in the commodity is the internati
componenttext: And Charlie, you mentioned -- worldwide, could you give us a little bit of help on what's domestic and what's outside the U.S? And in the U.S., geographically, are we in the oil patches where is this mostly occurring, and in the commodity is the international? Just a better feel for. And you gave some splits before on what impacted third quarter, what you think will impact fourth quarter. Just if you could give some splits around that, please, it would be helpful.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think if you think back [indiscernible] environmental solutions business, not in the U.S. but in other parts of the Americas as well. So when you think about that business for us, it's the U.S., it's Canada, it's Latin America. And when you look at
componenttext: Yes, I think if you think back [indiscernible] environmental solutions business, not in the U.S. but in other parts of the Americas as well. So when you think about that business for us, it's the U.S., it's Canada, it's Latin America. And when you look at where we're seeing this impact, we're seeing it unevenly across the businesses, bigger domestically, obviously. So when you look at the spit, it's about an 80-20 split, 80% affecting the U.S., 20% affecting international. And that's because of the scale of the business, Scott.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Al Kaschalk.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Al Kaschalk.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just on the expense items that were elevated, I'm not sure if I understood what those were, if that was just lower utilization. Just maybe a little bit more color on helping to explain the $0.03, $0.04 there that I think Dan has articulated.
componenttext: Just on the expense items that were elevated, I'm not sure if I understood what those were, if that was just lower utilization. Just maybe a little bit more color on helping to explain the $0.03, $0.04 there that I think Dan has articulated.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Absolutely, Al. When you're -- we have a couple fires in plants both internationally, and that does require, when you have that to temporarily redirect waste for a period of time, and that will carry forward into Q4. And that does come at a cost to be abl
componenttext: Absolutely, Al. When you're -- we have a couple fires in plants both internationally, and that does require, when you have that to temporarily redirect waste for a period of time, and that will carry forward into Q4. And that does come at a cost to be able to move those waste flows. Also, you've seen large inflation pressures in certain Latin American countries, in which there are large unions that cover our workforce down there. And we're required by regulation and within our union contracts due to the inflation to do a large, kind of unexpected payroll increase. And again, obviously, that is going to continue through. The other thing that we've learned is that we've upgraded the compliance of all of our domestic incinerators to meet Title V  requirements. Those come at operating at a higher cost. And I think, Brent, you could probably touch on that a bit of color to help you better understand why that happens.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, as we meet this new emission standards, what we're finding is higher operating costs, particularly associated with the ongoing maintenance of this new more stringent equipment to reach these levels. Examples would be our higher supply costs, increase
componenttext: Yes, as we meet this new emission standards, what we're finding is higher operating costs, particularly associated with the ongoing maintenance of this new more stringent equipment to reach these levels. Examples would be our higher supply costs, increased maintenance costs. And then when we have downtime, just the cost of moving it from one waste processing facility to the other is where we're experiencing that higher cost.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So does that last allow -- are these cost that you're going to absorb and not be able to pass along, or say, in '16, '17 over time, you will be prudent in getting the higher operating costs in your business out to your customers?
componenttext: So does that last allow -- are these cost that you're going to absorb and not be able to pass along, or say, in '16, '17 over time, you will be prudent in getting the higher operating costs in your business out to your customers?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Al. That' a good question. I think this is something that over time we can pass on to the customers, especially those customers that utilize incineration. Although we'll have to look contract by contract, and certainly, a lot of these increases go in
componenttext: Yes, Al. That' a good question. I think this is something that over time we can pass on to the customers, especially those customers that utilize incineration. Although we'll have to look contract by contract, and certainly, a lot of these increases go in when we have the contract come up for renewal. So certainly, it's something we feel we will get, but we think there will be a lag. We'll be able to get some of these costs back.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Erin Wilson.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Erin Wilson.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Can you just -- not really related to the topic, but can you just speak to the visibility on sort of that industrial waste business and kind of how concentrated is that? You mentioned several project, but really is it the vast majority of the concentrated
componenttext: Can you just -- not really related to the topic, but can you just speak to the visibility on sort of that industrial waste business and kind of how concentrated is that? You mentioned several project, but really is it the vast majority of the concentrated? And is it really an inherently lumpy business? Does it ever make sense to break it out similar to what you do in the returns business, given the volatility there?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, Erin, if we think about visibility, I mean, it came in Q3. And historically, in Q3, given in our medical waste service, July and August tend to be slower months for us. We see a bit of a revenue decline even on the health care side, as peopl
componenttext: Yes, I think, Erin, if we think about visibility, I mean, it came in Q3. And historically, in Q3, given in our medical waste service, July and August tend to be slower months for us. We see a bit of a revenue decline even on the health care side, as people take vacation. We have an increased cost of a lot of overtime that takes place in July and August. So as we were looking at the business, we saw the normal slowdown, usually the medical waste business bounces back like it did. On the industrial side, it did. And the project work is very lumpy. When you start making these pick-ups and you see the volume significantly lower, that's when you see that you're not getting that industrial waste volume that you'd like to see. And I think the fact that it weren't happening in Q3, we were looking at our normal July and August, we just didn't see the bounce-back, especially in the United States in that September time period.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Erin, just to add on that, I really don't think it does make sense to break that out. We're utilizing the same sales force, the same transportation fleet, the same facility. That's a percentage of the overall business that we serve, so it will be very
componenttext: And Erin, just to add on that, I really don't think it does make sense to break that out. We're utilizing the same sales force, the same transportation fleet, the same facility. That's a percentage of the overall business that we serve, so it will be very difficult to break that out.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, okay great. And then on the recalls business, kind of going forward, I guess it's kind of your standard guidance there for 2016. Is there -- how much, I guess, of it was automotive and in the most recent quarter? And how should we think about that c
componenttext: Okay, okay great. And then on the recalls business, kind of going forward, I guess it's kind of your standard guidance there for 2016. Is there -- how much, I guess, of it was automotive and in the most recent quarter? And how should we think about that component of the business going forward [indiscernible]?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Certainly, we continue to see a rebound in the recall business. If you recall, we started the year at about $20 million. And as Brent said in his prepared remarks, we had the highest amount in a quarter in 3 years of $30 million. We continue to see an une
componenttext: Certainly, we continue to see a rebound in the recall business. If you recall, we started the year at about $20 million. And as Brent said in his prepared remarks, we had the highest amount in a quarter in 3 years of $30 million. We continue to see an uneven business, but the auto sector continues to create opportunities. And Brent kind of talked about it in his opening comments, a lot of that is coming around the call center work. That does have some related lower margins. But we feel really good about where we are in that business, certainly for 2015 and for 4Q and for our 2015 results. When you think about the auto recalls and why we're excited about that, obviously, there's a heightened sensitivity to auto recalls in general. And if you think about Stericycle, we offer a turnkey solution for these manufacturers to help them assess their customers. So what do we do? We help them in notifying and we help to get their response rate up, and that's where they're getting a lot of pressure. So we think it's further adds to the solutions in the recall space. We don't break out certainly where we're getting these recalls from, but auto recall helps us get to that high level of a little over $30 million in the quarter.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Scott Levine.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Scott Levine.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I don't recall if you gave the gross margin bridge that you typically gave. If you did, I apologize. If you didn't, if you could offer that up. I'm just trying to get a better sense of the gross margins implicit in your guidance, if you back out some o
componenttext: So I don't recall if you gave the gross margin bridge that you typically gave. If you did, I apologize. If you didn't, if you could offer that up. I'm just trying to get a better sense of the gross margins implicit in your guidance, if you back out some of these -- the fees, the fires, et cetera, costs that were kind of nonrecurring in the quarter. Just trying to get a better sense of what the jumping off point is and whether we should continue to expect that underlying 10 to 20 basis points of sequential gross margin going forward. Or maybe a little bit more color on what Shred-it does for the margin outlook there.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Let me first give you the bridge. And we gave it before, but certainly, we're happy to do that for you again. The Q2 gross margin was 42.66, and we have the 40 basis points of unfavorability that came from the lower-than-expected project worldwide.
componenttext:
Sure. Let me first give you the bridge. And we gave it before, but certainly, we're happy to do that for you again. The Q2 gross margin was 42.66, and we have the 40 basis points of unfavorability that came from the lower-than-expected project worldwide. We did have those higher costs, and I gave a lot of color on that. It was 51 basis points. That's how you get to the 41.77. If you want to look at the guidance going forward, I would urge you to, for your modeling, let's focus on EBIT. As we work through mapping Shred-it expenses into Stericycle's structure from IFRS to GAAP, you're going to see changes in gross margin in SG&A. And so with
that, I think it's more important if you just look at it from an EBIT perspective. And I think the model going forward has about 268 basis point impact when we bring in Shred-it right now. So if you look at our EBIT, it was Q3, 23.6, about a 268 basis point impact when you include Shred-it into that number. You'll see about 55 basis points of improvement. So certainly, while we expect some of this to continue, you do see some nice expansion going in there as we work for the plan Charlie talked about. And I think for your modeling purposes, about a 20.6 EBIT for Q4, and that would put you at about full year of 22.3.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. And as a follow-up, very quickly, I think last quarter, you announced some -- in your international business some new markets for clinical services in Latin America. Any noteworthy trends in your international business, generally outperformers, ju
componenttext: Got it. And as a follow-up, very quickly, I think last quarter, you announced some -- in your international business some new markets for clinical services in Latin America. Any noteworthy trends in your international business, generally outperformers, just outliers and any additional traction within clinical services, to be aware of.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Brent. Absolutely, we continue to see good growth of our Sharps business in Latin America, where we've opened up some new facilities there. We talked a little bit more about that last quarter, but we continue to see real strong progress both in Br
componenttext: This is Brent. Absolutely, we continue to see good growth of our Sharps business in Latin America, where we've opened up some new facilities there. We talked a little bit more about that last quarter, but we continue to see real strong progress both in Brazil and Chile. And then from a clinical services, continue to be pleased by adoption rate and what the team is doing both in Spain and other parts of Europe.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015

So Shred-it, as we said on calls when we [indiscernible] the acquisition, from a pricing and a service, it logical fits in to the Stericycle offering.

componenttext: Good afternoon. My name is Dan, and I'll be your conference operator today. At this time, I'd like to welcome everyone to the Stericycle Third Quarter Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] I'll now turn the call over to VP of Corporate Finance, Mr. Sean McMillan. Please go ahead.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Welcome to Stericycle's Third Quarter 2015 Conference Call. I will now read the Safe Harbor statement. This conference call may contain forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties, some of which are beyond our control, for example, gen
componenttext:
Welcome to Stericycle's Third Quarter 2015 Conference Call. I will now read the Safe Harbor statement. This conference call may contain forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties, some of which are beyond our control, for example, general economic and market conditions. Our actual results could differ significantly from the results described in the forward-looking statements. Factors that could cause such differences include: changes in governmental regulations of the collection, transportation, treatment and disposal of regulated waste; increases in transportation and other operating costs; the level of governmental enforcement of regulations governing regulated waste collection and treatment; our ability to execute our acquisition strategy and to integrate acquired businesses; competition and demand for services in the regulated waste industry; political, economic and currency risks related to our foreign operations; impairments of goodwill or other indefinite-lived intangibles; exposure to environmental liabilities; compliance with existing and future legal and regulatory requirements; as well as other factors described in our filings with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission, including our most recently filed Annual Report on Form 10-K. 
As a result, past financial performance should not be considered a reliable indicator of future performance, and investors should not use historical trends to anticipate future results or trends. We make no commitment to disclose any subsequent revisions to forward-looking statements. 
I will now turn it over to Charlie Alutto, CEO.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you for joining us on today's call. In the third quarter, our results were unfavorably impacted by the following key factors: the strengthening of the U.S. dollar; lower hazardous waste volumes from our industrial customers; and some higher-than-ant
componenttext:
Thank you for joining us on today's call. In the third quarter, our results were unfavorably impacted by the following key factors: the strengthening of the U.S. dollar; lower hazardous waste volumes from our industrial customers; and some higher-than-anticipated expenses in certain lines of business. Although we are disappointed with the results of the third quarter, the long-term fundamentals of the company remains strong. We are encouraged by our continued success in selling additional services to our existing customer base and our growing recall and solutions business. Furthermore, we are very excited about the future growth provided by the recent Shred-it acquisition. 
Joining me on today's call to review our third quarter results will be Dan Ginnetti, CFO; and Brent Arnold, COO. I will now turn it over to Dan.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Charlie. The results for the third quarter are as follows. Revenues were $718.6 million, up 7.6% from $667.9 million in Q3 2014. And internal growth, excluding returns and recall revenues, was up 6.3%. Domestic revenues were $523.5 million, of
componenttext:
Thank you, Charlie. The results for the third quarter are as follows. Revenues were $718.6 million, up 7.6% from $667.9 million in Q3 2014. And internal growth, excluding returns and recall revenues, was up 6.3%. Domestic revenues were $523.5 million, of which $493.2 million was domestic regulated waste and compliance services, and $30.3 million was recalls and returns. Domestic internal growth, excluding recalls and returns revenues, was up 6%, consisting of SQ up 7% and LQ up 4%. Growth rates were unfavorably impacted by lower fuel surcharges and lower hazardous waste volume from our industrial customers. 
International revenues were $195.1 million, and internal growth adjusted for unfavorable foreign exchange impact of $33 million was up 8%. This growth rate was also unfavorably impacted by lower hazardous waste volume. 
Acquisitions contributed $33.3 million to growth in the quarter. Growth profit was $299.7 million or 41.7% of revenues. 
SG&A expense, including amortization, was $138 million or 19.2% of revenues. Net interest expense was $17.4 million. Net income attributable to Stericycle was $41.8 million or $0.47 per share on an as-reported basis and $1.08 when adjusted for acquisition-related expenses and other adjustments including the recent legal settlement. 
Now for the balance sheet. Our covenant debt to EBITDA ratio was 1.17 at the end of the quarter, which includes the equity from the recent mandatory convertible preferred issuance. The unused portion of the revolver at the end of the quarter was approximately $875 million. 
In the quarter, we repurchased 88,376 shares of common stock on the open market in an amount of $11.9 million. At the end of the quarter, we have authorization to purchase 4 million shares. 
Our CapEx was $25.8 million. Our DSO was 67 days. Year-to-date, reported cash from operations was $293 million. When adjusted for recall reimbursement and other items, cash from operations was $353 million. 
I'll now turn it over to Brent.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dan. This quarter, we closed 10 acquisitions: 3 domestic and 7 international. International acquisitions were 3 in South Korea, 2 in Spain and 2 in Romania. Revenues from the 10 acquisitions were $2.2 million in the quarter, and annualized are app
componenttext:
Thanks, Dan. This quarter, we closed 10 acquisitions: 3 domestic and 7 international. International acquisitions were 3 in South Korea, 2 in Spain and 2 in Romania. Revenues from the 10 acquisitions were $2.2 million in the quarter, and annualized are approximately $14.3 million. Our worldwide acquisition pool remains robust with well over $100 million in annualized revenues in multiple geographies and lines of business. 
In the quarter, we experienced solid growth in selling additional services to our existing customer base. This growth came from retail hazardous waste, Sharps Management, pharmaceutical waste and Communication Solutions. For example, we are seeing increased adoption of our pharmaceutical waste service by physician practices. By utilizing our existing customer relationships, along with our environmental solutions infrastructure, we are able to deliver a simple and cost-effective service that keeps our customers compliant and helps protect the environment. 
 
We also experienced solid growth in our recall and return business. The combination of our recall expertise and the relationships in the automotive sector are creating many opportunities. The team has done a terrific job of flexing up our call center capacity to meet the demand of several large engagements. This has resulted in our best recall and returns quarter in the past 3 years. 
On October 1, we closed the Shred-it acquisition. The acquisition team is off to a quick start, driving operational synergies and laying the groundwork for long-term growth. 
Today, less than 20% of our existing Stericycle customers utilize Shred-it for secure information destruction services. This acquisition provides another value-added service for our customers and an exciting growth opportunity for Stericycle. We would like to take this opportunity to welcome the Shred-it team members to our Stericycle family. Additionally, we thank all of our worldwide team members for their continued commitment to our customers, our shareholders and our values. 
I will now turn it over to Charlie.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Brent. I would now like to provide insight on our current guidance for 2015 and preliminary guidance for 2016. Please keep in mind that these are forward-looking statements, and our guidance does not include future acquisitions, divestitures, inte
componenttext:
Thanks, Brent. I would now like to provide insight on our current guidance for 2015 and preliminary guidance for 2016. Please keep in mind that these are forward-looking statements, and our guidance does not include future acquisitions, divestitures, integration, acquisition-related and other adjusted items. 
The current 2015 and preliminary 2016 guidance also includes the recently closed Shred-it acquisition, the related increase in share count and the impact of the strengthening U.S. dollar. 
For 2015, we believe that analyst EPS estimates will be in the range of $4.38 to $4.41. We believe analyst revenue estimates for 2015 will be approaching $3 billion, depending on assumptions for growth and negative impact from foreign exchange rates. 
We anticipate 2015 internal growth rates to be: SQ, 7% to 9%; LQ, 4% to 7%; international, 7% to 9%; and recall and returns revenues between $100 million and $110 million. 
We believe analysts will have estimates for 2015 free cash flow between $417 million to $426 million. 
2015 CapEx is anticipated to be between $104 million to $110 million. We expect the full year as-reported tax rate to be approximately 33.5% to 34%. This assumes the tax rate for the remainder of the year to be approximately 36%. 
Now I'd like to provide preliminary guidance for 2016. As a reminder, in 2016, we will be reporting on a cash EPS basis. For modeling purposes, our 2015 EPS guidance of $4.38 to $4.41 is equivalent to $4.69 to $4.72 on a cash EPS basis. 
For 2016, we believe analyst cash EPS estimates will be in the range of $5.28 to $5.35, using a share count of approximately 92 million, which we are comfortable with. 
For comparative purposes, when 2015 cash EPS is normalized for tax rates and foreign exchange impact, this represents a cash EPS growth rate of approximately 17%. We believe analyst revenue estimates for 2016 will be in the range of $3.65 billion to $3.72 billion, depending on assumptions for growth and negative impact from foreign exchange rates. 
We anticipate 2016 internal growth rates to be SQ, 7% to 9%; LQ, 4% to 7%; International, 6% to 9%; and recall and returns revenues between $95 million to $120 million. We believe analysts will have estimates for free cash flow in 2016 between $470 million to $485 million. 2016 CapEx is anticipated to be between $125 million to $140 million. We expect the 2016 full year as-reported tax rate to be approximately 36%. 
In closing, although disappointed with the results in Q3, we are confident about the long-term fundamentals of our business and remain excited about the growth opportunities in 2016 and beyond. 
Thank you for your time today. We'll now answer any questions. [Operator Instructions] Dan, you can now open the queue.

componenttext: Maybe the first one I can ask you to provide a bridge from the $1.18 you were thinking about for earnings per share in Q3, to which you reported, maybe highlighting the has waste impact and then higher expenses and perhaps a little color on what those both were.

componenttextpreview: Sure. Let me help you with that. So the estimates that are out, there were $1.19, anywhere from $1.18 to $1.19. Our guidance was $1.18. There's about a $0.01 difference between that. We saw $0.025 headwind from the additional equity and the continued FX i
componenttext: Sure. Let me help you with that. So the estimates that are out, there were $1.19, anywhere from $1.18 to $1.19. Our guidance was $1.18. There's about a $0.01 difference between that. We saw $0.025 headwind from the additional equity and the continued FX impact from the strengthening U.S. dollar. This slower-than-anticipated worldwide project work, along with the shift in customer mix in the recall business, created about a $0.05 headwind. SG&A investments in growth drivers, some higher professional fees and some higher-than-anticipated cost of revenues contributed to about $.025 of that myth. And that's how you would get to $1.08.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I guess my follow-up would be just looking at the cash EPS guidance for 2016. If we are assuming 10% accretion for Shred-it, so $0.47 cash EPS on the $4.70 midpoint this year. It looks like the core business EPS growth is going to be pretty
componenttext: Okay. And then I guess my follow-up would be just looking at the cash EPS guidance for 2016. If we are assuming 10% accretion for Shred-it, so $0.47 cash EPS on the $4.70 midpoint this year. It looks like the core business EPS growth is going to be pretty muted next year. So can you talk a little bit about that? Or maybe I'm doing some of the math wrong, but any color there?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let me help you a little bit with the math, and then I think Charlie can add a little bit of color to the future growth. When you look at the equivalent cash EPS that Charlie provided you for modeling purposes that was the $4.69 to the $4.72. Again, this
componenttext: Let me help you a little bit with the math, and then I think Charlie can add a little bit of color to the future growth. When you look at the equivalent cash EPS that Charlie provided you for modeling purposes that was the $4.69 to the $4.72. Again, this year, from a cash perspective, we had 2 large legal settlements, which significantly lowered our tax rate. We also had some great entity consolidation that we did earlier in the year, which provided a much lower tax rate. So when you normalize for that tax going to the 36 because we don't expect those are going to replicate, that's about $0.12 difference. Also, the continued foreign expense or foreign exchange escalation throughout the year is about another $0.04. So when you normalize for that, you would look at about a $4.53 to a $4.56, on average, $4.55. And what that provides you is about a 16 to 17.5 probably 17 in the middle quarter over -- or year-over-year growth.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think another way to look at it, Ryan, and obviously, we're being conservative with our guidance and that's related to the strengthening of the dollar, the reduction in the industrial waste volumes and further investments in the long-term growth en
componenttext: Yes, I think another way to look at it, Ryan, and obviously, we're being conservative with our guidance and that's related to the strengthening of the dollar, the reduction in the industrial waste volumes and further investments in the long-term growth engines. This guidance will allow the Stericycle management team to focus on those areas that provide predictable revenues and outcomes. And these areas include environmental solutions, Shred-it, Communication Solutions, as well as our medical waste and compliance services. If the industrial waste volumes rebound, that will be in addition to our strong growth that we're experiencing in the overall business.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015

componenttext: Well I guess I'm flummoxed, which doesn't happen very often. The forecast seems about $150 million light to me on the revenues. When you think about your ending this year at about $3 billion and there's $725 million is the number that was in the presentation for Shred-it, and you've got to grow the $3 billion and the $725 million has got to grow, so help me gap that difference.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think when you look at it, we think that, Michael, first of all, we think some of the industrial waste weakness that we've seen in Q3 is going to continue on and probably accelerate a little bit more in Q4, so we're being very conservative on the
componenttext: Well, I think when you look at it, we think that, Michael, first of all, we think some of the industrial waste weakness that we've seen in Q3 is going to continue on and probably accelerate a little bit more in Q4, so we're being very conservative on the industrial waste. If you think about our industrial waste part of the business, we've got about $125 million to $200 million of our regulated waste services that we feel is directly related to project or industrial waste business. So we think that slowdown, which we saw accelerate in Q3, is going to actually get worse in Q4 and then level off in 2016. Then we add the additional effect of the foreign exchange. Dan can walk you through some of those bridges, but we certainly have the additional foreign exchange headwind. It not only affected us this quarter, but if we'll use this rate going forward, which we do, it has an impact going into 2016 as well.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So just to be clear, out of your roughly at $520 million of hazardous waste, $125 million to $200 million that's project-based. And you see that number becoming what?
componenttext: So just to be clear, out of your roughly at $520 million of hazardous waste, $125 million to $200 million that's project-based. And you see that number becoming what?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we think that number for next year will be -- well, for next quarter, it could be down anywhere between $14 million -- $18 million to $20 million. And we were impacted roughly by about $8 million to $10 million in this quarter. So if you take that w
componenttext: Well, we think that number for next year will be -- well, for next quarter, it could be down anywhere between $14 million -- $18 million to $20 million. And we were impacted roughly by about $8 million to $10 million in this quarter. So if you take that weakness that we're showing in Q4 and you take that out into 2016, that right there is anywhere between $60 million to $70 million.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess, Q2, I'm wondering on the gross margin. Maybe you can get -- break that apart a little bit. Some of the items that you mentioned here in terms of SG&A investments and professional fees, clearly, those are more SG&A related. And on the GP, we've ne
componenttext: I guess, Q2, I'm wondering on the gross margin. Maybe you can get -- break that apart a little bit. Some of the items that you mentioned here in terms of SG&A investments and professional fees, clearly, those are more SG&A related. And on the GP, we've never really seen a drop like this. Is it that the profitability of this industrial waste is much higher than average or just a lack of absorption? What's the underlying cause of that, the gross margin weakness?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, David, I'll tell you. Why don't I start with the bridge and I'll add a little bit of color to that? So Q2 gross margins were $42.66 million. We did have some acquisitions, but the impact of that was offset directly with foreign exchange. We did have
componenttext: Sure, David, I'll tell you. Why don't I start with the bridge and I'll add a little bit of color to that? So Q2 gross margins were $42.66 million. We did have some acquisitions, but the impact of that was offset directly with foreign exchange. We did have 40 basis points of unfavorable impact that came from the lower-than-expected project work. And we had some higher-than-anticipated cost of revenues, about 51 basis points of unfavorability. What those word instances[indiscernible] that you asked about, those were redirection of waste flows required from 2 facility fires, payroll adjustment required by unions due to 2 -- due to inflation in 2 Latin American countries. We've experienced some higher operational costs from running our newly compliant Title V incinerators. Regarding the project work, yes, that does come out as higher. We have a certain amount of -- a significant amount of fixed cost that are tied to the industry. And when that revenue comes in, we're able to leverage those resources and go at them. We do have a plan going forward that Charlie had talked about on how to maybe flex that a little bit. But when that revenue comes off, we have to maintain the integrity of our fixed costs in our fleet to be able to continue to service that recurring business.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think as Dan said, Dave, the current fixed cost structure in environmental solutions, coupled with that unexpected lower revenues, unfavorably impacted revenues. I think the bigger question is what are we going to do to mitigate that in the future?
componenttext: Yes, I think as Dan said, Dave, the current fixed cost structure in environmental solutions, coupled with that unexpected lower revenues, unfavorably impacted revenues. I think the bigger question is what are we going to do to mitigate that in the future? Well, we're certainly going to implement plans to reduce those fixed cost within the business. If you think back, this is very similar to our approach and success we had in our recall business, where they solely have a business-based on project work. So we do need to mitigate that in the future by lowering those fixed costs on our environmental solutions out of the business.

The growth engines performed well when we looked at it from an additional services perspective, but certainly, we had headwinds related to fuel surcharges and those hazardous waste volumes. So we have adjusted the domestic LQ and SQ growth rates for 2015 and 2016, based on our assumptions that the headwinds, which we've outlined will remain -- will be in effect for 2015 and remain for 2016 as well.
