headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's a good question, so let's look at it. So our Q3 industrial wastes volumes worldwide were less than we anticipated. And Gary, that includes project work and lower volumes from the industrial waste customers. Obviously, we feel the shortfall in the p
componenttext: That's a good question, so let's look at it. So our Q3 industrial wastes volumes worldwide were less than we anticipated. And Gary, that includes project work and lower volumes from the industrial waste customers. Obviously, we feel the shortfall in the projects and these volumes are directly related to the drop in energy and commodity prices. And I think you kind of said it. We acquired assets over the last several years that included industrial waste customers, and these customers' volumes obviously are now included in our base business. So certainly, from a guidance perspective, since we thought that this pressure will not only continue but get slightly worse for the remainder of 2015, level out in 2016, that's why we took it out of our guidance in 2015 and for 2016. But it's certainly the acquisitions we've made were a portion of the businesses. I think you're absolutely right about that shouldn't be our focus. All along, we've talked about building an SQ recurring revenue model. We are certainly going to do that. We'll look at that with a little more gusto now that we've seen that project work, fluctuate more than we like. We saw it fluctuate in Q1. It came back in Q2. We thought we were going to be right there in Q3 and Q4, so this cost [ph] is obviously built during the quarter, but the focus will be over time is to transition this project in industrial waste work, which is not our core focus, to a more SQ recurring revenue model. For instance, like Steri-Safe for hazardous waste customers.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then a follow-up question, just on Shred-it. Can you -- within that guidance, I realized you may not break it down in a detailed fashion going forward, but can you give us a sense what is implied for Shred-it? Whether that's on the revenu
componenttext: Okay, great. And then a follow-up question, just on Shred-it. Can you -- within that guidance, I realized you may not break it down in a detailed fashion going forward, but can you give us a sense what is implied for Shred-it? Whether that's on the revenue line or the EBITDA line? Or just give us -- help us get to this new guidance frame what's in there for Shred-it?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Gary. I think when you're modeling for 2016, about $716 million is an appropriate range. Looking after EBIT, and I would urge you to look at us from an EBIT perspective as well, as we transition Shred-it which is a Canadian-owned company over to U.S
componenttext: Sure, Gary. I think when you're modeling for 2016, about $716 million is an appropriate range. Looking after EBIT, and I would urge you to look at us from an EBIT perspective as well, as we transition Shred-it which is a Canadian-owned company over to U.S. GAAP, IFRS to GAAP requires some changes. And so we'll see potentially some movements within gross margin and SG&A, but EBIT should be consistent. So I would model at about 16.7% for their EBIT. The depreciation in their model and amortization is about $56 million depreciation and $30 million amortization. And then figure about $35 million to $45 million in interest.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Scott Schneeberger.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Scott Schneeberger.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: You just mentioned on the last question that the hidden industrial waste came on quickly. It caught you a little off-guard. Could take us a little bit more in depth into what exactly happened, what exactly is it? And you're speaking to stabilization in 20
componenttext: You just mentioned on the last question that the hidden industrial waste came on quickly. It caught you a little off-guard. Could take us a little bit more in depth into what exactly happened, what exactly is it? And you're speaking to stabilization in 2016. Could you elaborate a little bit on, it's going to get worse in fourth quarter from third, stable in fourth quarter? Please kind of speak to what happened and what gives you the outlook of stabilization next year.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I think just so I paint the picture clearer, so we had obviously an impact in Q3. We think that impact will get slightly worse in Q4 and then it will stay at that level into 2016. So it will stay at that low level, that's at least from a guidance
componenttext: Yes. So I think just so I paint the picture clearer, so we had obviously an impact in Q3. We think that impact will get slightly worse in Q4 and then it will stay at that level into 2016. So it will stay at that low level, that's at least from a guidance perspective. And we might prove out to be too conservative on that, but we think it's prudent to have that view of the business at this point. To give you an example, Scott, on what do we mean by that type of work, I'll give you kind of 2 examples. And I think if you think through, as I said before, although we don't directly work with energy or mining companies, many of our customers do work for these industries. So the rate of decline, when we look at these customers, was much faster than we anticipated, and it declined rapidly in the quarter. So 2 examples I think we look at, we've had that's servicing and customer for several years that provides generators to the oil and gas industry. This customer provided very steady volumes over the last several years. Their business was down by over 70%, when we look at that specific example, Q3 year-over-year. Another example, we had a contract with a customer that provides equipment cleaning services for the energy and the mining industry. In Q3, we experienced an 80% decline, again, related to the energy and commodity prices. So they're just 2 examples. Obviously, we've been negatively impacted from this. And I think as we stated, we just really want to be very conservative on the guidance, that's why we're taking guidance down for the rest of the year and having that continued to the business in 2016. If it comes back, it will just be additive to our growing core business.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Charlie, you mentioned -- worldwide, could you give us a little bit of help on what's domestic and what's outside the U.S? And in the U.S., geographically, are we in the oil patches where this is mostly occurring, and in the commodity is the internati
componenttext: And Charlie, you mentioned -- worldwide, could you give us a little bit of help on what's domestic and what's outside the U.S? And in the U.S., geographically, are we in the oil patches where this is mostly occurring, and in the commodity is the international? Just a better feel for. And you gave some splits before on what impacted third quarter, what you think will impact fourth quarter. Just if you could give some splits around that, please, it would be helpful.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think if you think back Stericycle was built in an environmental solutions business, not in the U.S. but in other parts of the Americas as well. So when you think about that business for us, it's the U.S., it's Canada, it's Latin America. And when
componenttext: Yes, I think if you think back Stericycle was built in an environmental solutions business, not in the U.S. but in other parts of the Americas as well. So when you think about that business for us, it's the U.S., it's Canada, it's Latin America. And when you look at where we're seeing this impact, we're seeing it evenly across the businesses, bigger domestically, obviously. So when you look at the split, it's about an 80-20 split, 80% affecting the U.S., 20% affecting international. And that's just because of the scale of the business, Scott.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Bill [sic] Al Kaschalk.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Bill [sic] Al Kaschalk.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just on the expense items that were elevated, I'm not sure if I understood what those were, if that was just lower utilization. Just maybe a little bit more color on helping to explain the $0.03, $0.04 there that I think Dan has articulated.
componenttext: Just on the expense items that were elevated, I'm not sure if I understood what those were, if that was just lower utilization. Just maybe a little bit more color on helping to explain the $0.03, $0.04 there that I think Dan has articulated.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Absolutely, Al. When you're -- we have a couple fires in plants both internationally, and that does require, when you have that to temporarily redirect waste for a period of time, and that will carry forward into Q4. And that does come at a cost to be abl
componenttext: Absolutely, Al. When you're -- we have a couple fires in plants both internationally, and that does require, when you have that to temporarily redirect waste for a period of time, and that will carry forward into Q4. And that does come at a cost to be able to move those waste flows. Also, you've seen large inflation pressures in certain Latin American countries, in which there are large unions that cover our workforce down there. And we're required by regulation and within our union contracts due to the inflation to do a large, kind of unexpected payroll increase. And again, obviously, that is going to continue through. The other thing that we've learned is that we've upgraded the compliance of all of our domestic incinerators to meet Title V  requirements. That those come at operating at a higher cost. And I think, Brent, could probably touch on that a bit of color to help you better understand why that happens.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, as we meet this new emission standards, what we're finding is were experiencing higher operating costs, particularly associated with the ongoing maintenance of this new more stringent equipment to reach these levels. Examples would be our higher supp
componenttext: Yes, as we meet this new emission standards, what we're finding is were experiencing higher operating costs, particularly associated with the ongoing maintenance of this new more stringent equipment to reach these levels. Examples would be our higher supply costs, increased maintenance costs. And then when we have downtime, just the cost of moving it from one waste processing facility to the other is where we're experiencing that higher cost.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So does that allow -- are these costs that you're going to absorb and not be able to pass along, or say, in '16, '17 over time, you will be prudent in getting the higher operating costs in your business out to your customers?
componenttext: So does that allow -- are these costs that you're going to absorb and not be able to pass along, or say, in '16, '17 over time, you will be prudent in getting the higher operating costs in your business out to your customers?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Al. That' a good question. I think this is something that over time we can pass on to the customers, especially those customers that utilize incineration. Although we'll have to look contract by contract, and certainly, a lot of these increases go in
componenttext: Yes, Al. That' a good question. I think this is something that over time we can pass on to the customers, especially those customers that utilize incineration. Although we'll have to look contract by contract, and certainly, a lot of these increases go in when we have the contract come up for renewal. So certainly, it's something we feel we will get, but we think there will be a lag. We'll be able to get some of these costs back.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Erin Wilson.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Erin Wilson.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Can you just -- not to belabor the topic, but can you just speak to the visibility on sort of that industrial waste business and kind of how concentrated is that? You mentioned several projects, but really is it the vast majority of the concentrated? And
componenttext: Can you just -- not to belabor the topic, but can you just speak to the visibility on sort of that industrial waste business and kind of how concentrated is that? You mentioned several projects, but really is it the vast majority of the concentrated? And is it really an inherently lumpy business? Does it ever make sense to break it out similar to what you do in the returns business, given the volatility there?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, Erin, if we think about visibility for it, I mean, it came in Q3. And historically, in Q3, given in our medical waste service, July and August tend to be slower months for us. We see a bit of a revenue decline even on the health care side, a
componenttext: Yes, I think, Erin, if we think about visibility for it, I mean, it came in Q3. And historically, in Q3, given in our medical waste service, July and August tend to be slower months for us. We see a bit of a revenue decline even on the health care side, as people take vacation. We have an increased cost of a lot of overtime that takes place in July and August. So as we were looking at the business, we saw the normal slowdown, usually the medical waste business bounces back like it did. On the industrial side, it did. And the project work is very lumpy. When you start making these pick-ups and you see the volume significantly lower, that's when you see that you're not getting that industrial waste volume that you'd like to see. And I think the fact of where it happened in Q3, we were looking at our normal July and August, we just didn't see the bounce-back, especially in the United States in that September time period.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Erin, just to add on that, I really don't think it does make sense to break that out. We're utilizing the same sales force, the same transportation fleet, the same facility. That's a percentage of the overall business that we serve, so it will be very
componenttext: And Erin, just to add on that, I really don't think it does make sense to break that out. We're utilizing the same sales force, the same transportation fleet, the same facility. That's a percentage of the overall business that we serve, so it will be very difficult to break that out.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, okay great. And then on the recalls business, kind of going forward, I guess it's kind of your standard guidance there for 2016. Is there -- how much, I guess, of it was automotive and in the most recent quarter? And how should we think about that c
componenttext: Okay, okay great. And then on the recalls business, kind of going forward, I guess it's kind of your standard guidance there for 2016. Is there -- how much, I guess, of it was automotive and in the most recent quarter? And how should we think about that component of the business going forward did that offer up, I guess [indiscernible]?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Certainly, we continue to see a rebound in the recall business. If you recall, we started the year at about $20 million. And as Brent said in his prepared remarks, we had the highest amount in a quarter in 3 years of $30 million. We continue to see an une
componenttext: Certainly, we continue to see a rebound in the recall business. If you recall, we started the year at about $20 million. And as Brent said in his prepared remarks, we had the highest amount in a quarter in 3 years of $30 million. We continue to see an uneven business, but the auto sector continues to create opportunities. And Brent even talked about it in his opening comments, a lot of that is coming around the call center work. That does have some related lower margins. But we feel really good about where we are in that business, certainly for 2015 and for 4Q and for our 2015 results. When you think about the auto recalls and why we're excited about that, obviously, there's a heightened sensitivity to auto recalls in general. And if you think about Stericycle, we offer a turnkey solution for these manufacturers to help them assess their customers. So what do we do? We help them in notifying and we help to get their response rate up, and that's where they're getting a lot of pressure. So we think it's further adds to the solutions in the recall space. We don't break out certainly where we're getting these recalls from, but auto recall helps us get to that high level of a little over $30 million in the quarter.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Scott Levine.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Scott Levine.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I don't recall if you gave the gross margin bridge that you typically gave. If you did, I apologize. If you didn't, if you could offer that up. I'm just trying to get a better sense of the gross margins implicit in your guidance, if you back out some o
componenttext: So I don't recall if you gave the gross margin bridge that you typically gave. If you did, I apologize. If you didn't, if you could offer that up. I'm just trying to get a better sense of the gross margins implicit in your guidance, if you back out some of these -- the fees, the fires, et cetera, costs that were kind of nonrecurring in the quarter. Just trying to get a better sense of what the jumping off point is and whether we should continue to expect that underlying 10 to 20 basis points of sequential gross margin going forward. Or maybe a little bit more color on what Shred-it does for the margin outlook there.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Let me first give you the bridge. And we gave it before, but certainly, we're happy to do that for you again. The Q2 gross margin was 42.66, and we have the 40 basis points of unfavorability that came from the lower-than-expected project worldwide.
componenttext:
Sure. Let me first give you the bridge. And we gave it before, but certainly, we're happy to do that for you again. The Q2 gross margin was 42.66, and we have the 40 basis points of unfavorability that came from the lower-than-expected project worldwide. We did have those higher costs, and I gave a lot of color on that. It was 51 basis points. That's how you get to the 41.77. If you want to look at the guidance going forward, I would urge you to, for your modeling, let's focus on EBIT. As we work through mapping Shred-it expenses into Stericycle's structure from IFRS to GAAP, you're going to see changes in gross margin in SG&A. And so with
that, I think it's more important if you just look at it from an EBIT perspective. And I think the model going forward has about 268 basis point impact when we bring in Shred-it right now. So if you looked at our EBIT, it was Q3, 23.6, about a 268 basis point impact when you include Shred-it into that number. You'll see about 55 basis points of improvement. So certainly, while we expect some of this to continue, you do see some nice expansion going in there as we work toward the plan Charlie talked about. And I think for your modeling purposes, about a 20.6 EBIT for Q4, and that would put you at about full year of 22.3.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. And as a follow-up, very quickly, I think last quarter, you announced some -- in your international business some new markets for clinical services in Latin America. Any noteworthy trends in your international business, generally outperformers, ju
componenttext: Got it. And as a follow-up, very quickly, I think last quarter, you announced some -- in your international business some new markets for clinical services in Latin America. Any noteworthy trends in your international business, generally outperformers, just outliers and any additional traction within clinical services, to be aware of.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Brent. Absolutely, we continue to see good growth of our Sharps business in Latin America, where we've opened up some new facilities there. We talked a little bit more about that last quarter, but we continue to see real strong progress growth bot
componenttext: This is Brent. Absolutely, we continue to see good growth of our Sharps business in Latin America, where we've opened up some new facilities there. We talked a little bit more about that last quarter, but we continue to see real strong progress growth both in Brazil and Chile. And then from a clinical services, continue to be pleased by adoption rate and what the team is doing both in Spain and the other parts of Europe.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Isaac Ro.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Isaac Ro.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to start maybe, Dan, with a question on CapEx and free cash flow. If we sort of look at the guidance you've given for 2016, it does look a bit of a step up here. And I'm wondering to the extent to which that might be a onetime increase or is it s
componenttext: I wanted to start maybe, Dan, with a question on CapEx and free cash flow. If we sort of look at the guidance you've given for 2016, it does look a bit of a step up here. And I'm wondering to the extent to which that might be a onetime increase or is it sort of a new run rate that we should think about for the long term.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: A step up in guidance for free cash flow, are you talking to particularly?
componenttext: A step up in guidance for free cash flow, are you talking to particularly?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, not in guidance, just on the absolutely number year-on-year, its material increase year-on-year. So I'm curious if that's the run rate or is it sort of a onetime thing, either, as it relates to, getting Shred-it integrated and all that?
componenttext: Well, not in guidance, just on the absolutely number year-on-year, its material increase year-on-year. So I'm curious if that's the run rate or is it sort of a onetime thing, either, as it relates to, getting Shred-it integrated and all that?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the big chunk of that, obviously, is going to come from Shred-it. I think what you're looking at is the guidance year-over-year of about 13% increase, which is in line with the growth that we'll give you. Remember, we helped you normalize for
componenttext: Yes, I think the big chunk of that, obviously, is going to come from Shred-it. I think what you're looking at is the guidance year-over-year of about 13% increase, which is in line with the growth that we'll give you. Remember, we helped you normalize for what the real performance was is going to be over the tax and foreign exchange. Seeing about a 13% increase, I think that's in line. I think it's conservative as we usually are coming out in 2016, and we will continue to work on things such as our DSO and improve that and continue to bring in the cash that will help us continue to grow the business.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. That's helpful. And then maybe just a general question on the overall operating environment, specifically with regards to pricing. Just curious what your assumptions are for '16 versus '15. Any change there and maybe help us understand or remind u
componenttext: Got it. That's helpful. And then maybe just a general question on the overall operating environment, specifically with regards to pricing. Just curious what your assumptions are for '16 versus '15. Any change there and maybe help us understand or remind us how the pricing environment in the Shred-it business may differ from the core?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Nothing overwhelming in the pricing, we feel, in going into 2016 as compared to 2015. And as we've said before, one of the things we like about Shred-it and their services, it's really not volume-driven. So really it really fits in well with our norm
componenttext: Yes. Nothing overwhelming in the pricing, we feel, in going into 2016 as compared to 2015. And as we've said before, one of the things we like about Shred-it and their services, it's really not volume-driven. So really it really fits in well with our normal SQ business, where you go to a stop and you check certain bins. It's more about bin tips and collections then it is about volume. And if you think about it, that's very similar to some of our SQ offerings like Steri-Safe and even some of our Communication Solutions offerings, which are not really volume-based. So Shred-it, as we said on calls when we first did the acquisition, from a pricing and a service, it logical fits in to the Stericycle offering.
